description:
This is my favorite dimsum to go spot. Everything is fairly priced and the quality is the best I've had compared to other dimsum Togo spots.

This is a cash only place . So make sure you brought enough! It's easy to get carried away 

The big bun - cheap $2-3(forgot T_T) and super filling but it taste good too! A large sized bao stuffed with chicken, chinese sausage, boiled egg, mushroom and delicious flavors 

Chinese tamale - it is freakin so tasty and huge !surrounded with sticky rice. The filling contains salted egg yolk, chinese sausage, fatty pork, lean pork, shiitake mushroom, lotus seeds, chestnut .. it is freakin tasty . Yes I said it twice 

Black sesame paste dessert - think of it as a thicken soup instead of a paste. If you never had it before than you would just have to try to see if you like the texture. But I think this is the best black sesame paste you can get around unless you make your own from scratch or go to a very nice chinese restaurant that may serve it which  is rare to none. Taste like black sesame and not watered down glob like most places 

White sugar cake (bak tong go)- the white sponge looking thing. Slightly sweet classic dimsum dessert. I don't know how I should explain the texture but this place makes it right. Why? Because you know it's good when it doesn't have a sour taste to it. Has to do with the steaming process I've heard. 

Steamed pudding ( boot jai go ) I don't know the English name for this but it's just another classic old style dessert that's steamed in bowls with some red beans in it and taken out and cooled before eaten. Rarely any places makes this but I could be wrong 

All the other stuff is decent. I mean it's a to go spot !
author: Myron L.

description:
Unless you have a nose for dim sum, you will walk past TC Pastry on Irving Street if you don't pay much attention to storefronts.

If you find this place on accident, like me, you may wonder "what is this hole in a wall joint that I must try?"

Try you shall. Because, it is solid. Real solid.

By solid I don't mean the next Koi Palace or Yank Sing. Don't expect caviar or fancy roe sprinkled on your shumai. However, by solid I will sign off that TC Pastry is one of the better take out dim sum joints in SF. Better than most spots in Chinatown or on Clement St.

Their Chicken and pork dumplings (shu mai) were excellent. Rice paper skin not too soggy but overall it's also not too dry. I thought it was done right. Oh, and their price - 3 dumplings for $2.25 - I mean, we unwillingly spend way more on SF restaurant's "health inspection fee"

Another winner is the lotus leaf wrapped rice with mince pork. A giant-sized deliciousness cooked to perfection.

Point of my review is, the next time you're on Irving St., between 20th-22nd, look around; you will find paradise.
author: Dave K.

description:
My brother has been to the TC Pastry in Daly City a few times, and he enjoys their dim sum items, so my dad and I decided to give this location a try after spending the day in Golden Gate Park. We went in the late afternoon so many of their more popular items were already sold out. I was lucky enough to snag the last egg tart. They have all kinds of dim sum items, from rice rolls to vegetarian buns to curry pastries. In addition, they have some cooked dishes (e.g., fried rice, chow mein) and some dessert items. Everything is extremely cheap here, and you can get a very filling meal for just a few dollars. 

My dad and I were just looking for a light snack, so we got one egg tart, one mango pudding, and one tofu pudding. The egg tart cost $1.20, and it was pretty solid. The pastry shell was flaky and buttery, and the custard filling was soft and creamy. The mango pudding came in a small container and cost about $2.50. The flavoring tasted very artificial, but it was still tasty. The consistency was smooth and velvety. I didn't try the tofu pudding but my dad complained that it was room temperature even though they advertised it as hot. Worst of all, there were black spots in his tofu pudding. I'm not sure what the spots were but it looked like mold. 

Food safety is extremely questionable here. The store was pretty dirty, and the staff didn't pay much attention to proper food handling. I was thinking of buying a box of pastries to take home to my family, but after finding the black spots in my dad's tofu pudding, I decided against that idea. The staff were unfriendly and rushed us when we ordered and snapped at us when we asked for napkins. Also, they charge 25 cents for each to go container.

There's no doubt that TC has cheap prices and a large selection, but it's not worth getting food poisoning for.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Authentic, affordable, not the best place for people who aren't already familiar with chinese dim sum. This place only takes cash which could be inconvenient but the food definitely makes up for it.
author: Ana F.

description:
$5.05 for SIX pastries? Worth & Yummy!

After grabbing iTea, I was just looking for a salty snack to complement the sweetness of my drink, and I happened to stumble upon this humble dim sum express. One word to explain this place would be utility because their interior and presentation did not appear so appealing. But, don't just the book by its cover, the food was awesome and extremely cheap!

WHAT I ORDERED: (3) Sesame Ball & (3) Deep Fried Curry Pastry = $5.05.

When I came in during the late afternoon, due to my cynicism, I just assumed what I bought would be somewhat stale or hardened. It didn't look too good through the displays, and I didn't check Yelp prior to see their positive reviews until after I took a bite in my order. 

Boy, was I wrong... the quality was good! The Sesame Ball had a nice mochi texture and a sweet yellow lotus filling that was simply delicious. The Deep Fried Curry Pastry was lightly crunchy on the outside and savory on the inside from its curry filling. Plus, both the size and quantity was enough to share with another person---which I gladly did not since it was too delish!

To add on top of that, for non-Chinese speakers, although workers mainly speak Chinese there, there are English labels on the display to help out, and the workers can get by through simple English. Customer service was good too. I look young, and they treated me fairly so no complaints there. There may be cultural differences, but hey, it's the food that counts.  

Overall, next time I decide to visit the Golden Gate Park, I'm definitely first going to stop by here to satisfy my afternoon munchies, especially when it's low-cost and high-quality.
author: Linda X.

description: A lot of dim sum choices and most are $.80 each other few dollars for 3 or something. So cheap! I didn't like their porridge though, it's not that good. I would skip. It's cash only!
author: Debbie D.

description: Tasty and cheap dim sum in a no frills take out shop setting.
author: Justin L.

description:
I'm shocked that I've never reviewed TC Pastry because I absolutely loved this place when I was in college. 

It was literally one of my staples, although I've always had the hardest time remembering their name. When I was a very broke college student my good friend Geoff and I would split a trip coming here, he would drive and I would buy and we'd get like $20 in dim sum - enough to last us a week!

The service has always been very quick and prompt, even if the space itself is a bit run of the mill. But the food was and is always incredibly delicious (the honey and I made a recent trip and he loved it) and I myself absolutely adore their taro!

 Definitely highly recommended if you're in the area!
author: Meg T.

description:
**CASH ONLY**

Where do I start? I was starved and was craving porridge badly. Thanks to Yelp, I found this place nearby.

Porridge with preserved egg and pork: Not too thick, but not too watery. The amount of preserved egg and pork was reasonable. For the price? You really can't complain. A large was $3.80 or so.

Beef cherng fun: Skin was soft and nice amount of beef.

Turnip cake: Pretty good especially with sriracha.

Baked BBQ pork buns: Not bad. Standard.

Everything is relatively cheap which makes this place so amazing. You can get full with $5 or less. Highly recommend for cheap dim sum.
author: Julian Y.

description:
Have been stopping at this place for snacks whenever we drive from, or to, SFO (from the North Bay). The dim sums are pretty standards. The conge is okay, so is the creamy black sesame paste. However, recently, they started offering the soya pudding. This is now our favorite. It is so smooth and silky. IMHO, it is better than a lot of the better known dim sum restaurants. 
Hope that they continue to come up with new yummy dim sums.
author: Andrew L.

description: Cheap and delicious dim sum.  I love that it has a quick to-go atmosphere so you don't have to sit in fancy restaurants and pay for overpriced dimsum.
author: Amy T.

description: My go to dim sum place to grab and go! Their dim sum is made fresh and it's tasty not to mention economical as well! If you're in the Sunset, grab some boba milk tea from Wonderful foods and some dim sum here and you're all set!
author: Colleen L.

description:
I like to come here to pick up dim sum and other small Asian eats. This is more of a to go place than a sit down place, but they do have some tables if you want to eat there.

They have a good variety. My favorites are chives dumplings, the sponge cake (馬來糕), custard buns, black sesame soup, and mango pudding in the fridge! The price is pretty good too, probably around half the price of dim sum in a sit down restaurant. 

They don't speak great English though and mostly Cantonese so they've given me the wrong item before. I still enjoyed it though, so all good.
author: Tiffany J.

description:
My go-to dim sum place!

I needed 2 dozen of peach buns (represents longevity in the Chinese culture and is usually displayed at birthday celebrations) and needed them in less than 24 hours. I had remember seeing them at TC Pastry before and when I called them at 6pm to ask if they could have it ready in less than 24 hours, they said no problem. I placed an order with them for 2 dozen and 1 giant peach bun and they told me to pick up at 4pm before before 3pm they are working on dim sum. 

They did tell me ahead of time to bring a tray so they can help me place it as a display. As soon as I got there, they had the peach buns ready and the price for 2 dozen small peach buns and 1 big one was not bad at all, for only $16.50. 

I highly recommend them if you need peach buns or even dim sum for your co-workers and family/friends!
author: Eva O.

description:
The preserved (black) egg and pork rice porridge (jook) here is excellent! It's $3.50 plus tax for a larger order. I also like their sticky rice dumpling; their shrimp chives/cilantro dumplings are especially good and it's got lots of shrimp inside, not cheap filler.

The folks at the counter give quick, efficient service. I order take-out only but there are tables inside if you want to sit and eat your order right then.
author: Everso T.

description: T & C Pastry, the only restaurant I would recommend on the whole street, you can get  a small bowl of Jook for a grand total of $2.40, no tax!( fills you up all day, they even throw in thousand-yr. egg & pork bits..  ..Between 23rd & 24th street, try it , you will not regret it..Food items are limited..  ..long fried breakfast  rolls you can try( don't have my wheelbarrow with me..); This & Popeye's chicken & Super burger(all you can drink, all the pickles, too..)is the only 3 restaurants in entire bay area worth spending $..  ..
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
Wonderful place for cheap takeout dim sum that I like better than any place I've been to in Chinatown. There's also a few tables for seating, which is nice. 

There's a pretty classic assortment of dumplings and you get a slight discount if you buy 3 or more. Cash only. 

Personal favorites are any of the shrimp dumplings, the pot stickers, and egg tart. The BBQ pork buns are just okay.
author: Hali M.

description:
This is Jook Time's other store.  Since they closed Jook Time I came here to buy dim sum.  Food prices were on par as JT.  However the bbq pork buns were disgusting.  They had bits of burnt parts and god knows what mixed in.

So disappointing.
author: Wendy H.

description:
I used to like the other location better! The prices at this location is all different for every single thing! The other location isn't like this and I think the prices are slightly cheaper. The quality is just ok. The size is TINY! Other location has a lot more better tasting and different food than this one. 

The women are quick at taking orders and handing you your food. The lady that helped me this morning (Jan 5, 2014) was nice and understood my Chinglish quite well. Hahaha!

Good cheap food if you're in the area.

CASH ONLY

Friendly ladies with a solid variety of dim sum. Items are priced per piece, and per order; which is a rare but nice option. TC's was busy when I got there but the line moved quickly. Lots of clean tables and chairs to dine in. Parking isn't too terrible depending on the time of day. If you're apprehensive to try, give it a go. The food was tasty and the prices were decent.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
TC Pastry offers delicious dim sum and entree items at very low prices. 

If you're looking to get dim sum without the whole sit-down experience, this is the place to go. The items and prices are stated clearly on the menu so there's no confusion. This is a cash only place. Many of the items are $1.50 - $3 so you're able to get your fill without feeling like you have to break the bank. There are a few tables available for seating but I've often just purchased a few dim sum items to-go. The porridge is delicious and the portion is quite generous. The buns are very huge and are served warm. 

There is often a long line here but the service is quick so I usually have to wait about 5 minutes. There is street parking available in the neighborhood.
author: Katie C.

description:
In my opinion as well as friends and family, this place has the best baked Cha siu bao.  The bread is so soft and there is just enough bao to eat with the filling in the middle.  Other places have way too much bun and not enough filling- this place gets it right.  The TC Pastry in Daly City has too much bun.
The "Gee Ma Wu" - Black sesame soup is so good here- try it!  All he other Dim Sum is good too.  But my main reason to go there is for the Cha siu bao that is baked.
author: Laurie L.

description: Decent dim sum but not the fanciest place to dine in. You can drop by here and pick a pretty good spread for a picnic or party.
author: W A.

description: Great hidden dim sum spot to go. One of the few spots that actually had fish and peanut porridge. Also, for people who don't speak Chinese, the people hear understand and speak pretty good English!
author: Eric C.

description: This place was a few blocks from our place and holds a special place in my heart and tummy. I'm for more mom and pop shops/restaurants and this place gives you that vibe. They have seriously the best dim sum and has always had my cravings sufficed. I love the steam buns and anything with shrimp in it, oh my! Soooooo good!!! We used to come here at least once a week or once every two weeks and refused to try anywhere else. The prices are unbeatable and the parking is easier to find than on Geary or Clement. Please expect to pay cash unless they upgraded to the card option.
author: Ashley P.

description: Fantastic takeout dim sum for excellent prices. The baked and steamed pork buns, and the custard buns, (and everything else) was delicious. I love this place!
author: Ed H.

description: Restaurant Name Dim Sum Specialist. The place looks dirty everywhere. Foods are cold all of them. I bought many foods yesterday, one of them it was Chinese Doughnuts. I can't finished it all I bought, so I put it in fridge for overnight till next day I eat and warm it up, realize there is a strong smell on it like chemicals, smell like formalin. The sameday in the morning after wake up, I went to restroom got Diarrhea. Food taste are bad not good at all. It was my first walk in to that restaurant. I'm not sure if they ever got inspection from San Franciso health department. Anyway just give a heads up for whoever want to buy their foods.
author: Zedong M.

description: Love the baked pork buns & taro balls!
author: Lexy C.

description:
Old food n cold
Makes me want to gag
How can they sell old cold food n microwave
Gross
I have other joints
author: Sarah C.

description:
3.5 STARS

My parents wanted to have dinner the other night, but I was sick. What do I crave when I'm sick?! Congee, chinese porridge, jook, whatever you wanna call it. And I wanted it with preserved egg (or leather egg, thousand year old egg, it has so many names)! Since my parents were going to be in the Sunset, my mom brought me some jook and dim sum from TC Pastry. It was Saturday, October 3rd around 2:30pm.

*Rice porridge with duck egg
*Chinese donut

My mom made me pei dan sau yuk jook (rice porridge with duck egg, it comes with pork too) a lot when I was little, so I crave it often when I'm sick or if I just want something comforting. Their version had a good amount of egg and good flavor. To me, jook is not complete without a yau ja gwai (chinese donut)! Theirs was super oily, so I had to take numerous paper towels to soak up all the oil. It was crispy on the outside and soft inside, so once I soaked up the oil, I had my little bowl of comfort.

*Fresh shrimp crepe roll
*Shrimp dumpling
*Pork dumpling
*Sticky rice ball with Chinese sausage
*Mini egg custard

Since I've have TC Pastry bookmarked for their dim sum, I asked my mom to grab me some. Their ha gow (shrimp dumpling) and ha cheong (fresh shrimp crepe roll) were both tasty. The shrimp was tender in both and the wrappers soft with a slight chew. The siu mai (pork dumpling) was just okay. I've had better. Sticky rice buns are another item that remind me of being a kid. Unfortunately it got soggy in the bag and could have used a little more sausage, but it fulfilled my sticky rice craving. I'd pass next time on the mini dan tats (egg custard). The crust is the cake kind, not the flaky one and they weren't very good. Kinda wished my mom had bought me a regular big dan tat instead.

While their dim sum was okay, their porridge provided me the comfort I needed when I wasn't feeling well. I'd probably pass next time on the dim sum, but if I'm in the area, their jook will do the trick!
author: Elena N.

description:
I LOOOOVE tc pastry. 

To be honest it's a bit aggravating that a lot of the negative reviews are towards the "crap" customer service. I'm sorry but if you're paying a dollar for three pieces of dimsum, you can't expect great customer service. They make their dimsum fresh everyday and I can't even imagine making hundreds of dimsum and other pastries everyday. Now, if this were a 5 star restaurant and then I'd complain. But cmon people. This is dimsum and savory meat buns. You can walk in here with $5 and feed a group of 3. Who cares if they don't smile at you or not. 

Personally they're always been nice to me. And I don't expect them to greet me with a welcoming "hello!" All I care about is that I'm buying delicious dimsum for a very affordable price. Plus as I've mentioned, their food is so good! I'm so obsessed with the shrimp crepe roll and the pork and shrimp dimsum. The sweet soysauce they give is also really good. I wonder how they make it 

I gave it 4/5 stars only because I wish they tidied the place up a bit. But again, who cares. Maybe it's just me since I don't care about little things like that. But this is definitely my go-to dimsum place when I'm in the Irving area.
author: Alex D.

description:
Just stopped by here for lunch on my day off. Not too shabby, good place to stop by if you're in the neighborhood for a cheap snack or lunch. 

Rating Breakdown:
1/2 Stars for Taste --
I saw the zhaliang on display and I knew I had to try it. For those of you who are unfamiliar, it's basically a fried Chinese donut, wrapped in steamed rice noodles, and topped with sweet soy sauce and peanut sauce. Definitely worth trying, but it's a LOT, so bring a friend or two to share with. Leftover zhaliang are no good = soggy mess. They cut the pieces into these huge chunks. I made the mistake of making eye contact with the lady behind the counter just as I stuffed an entire piece, smothered in peanut sauce, into my mouth. Let's just say this is one eligible med student she will NOT be introducing her son to. 

The dim sum items were pretty disappointing. I got a turnip cake and two shumai (beef and pork) and they were served cold. The beef shumai had tendon chunks in it that kept getting stuck in my teeth. 

1/1 Stars for Value --
At about 70cents a piece for dim sum ($2.00-$2.10 for 3 pieces), you get what you paid for. Maybe they'll taste better if you take them home and nuke 'em in the microwave first? Also, the heaping portion of zhaliang that you get for less than $3 (I think it was $2.70?) is a great deal!

0.5/1 Stars for Customer Service --
Typical dim sum place where you have to use a lot of pointing to order if you don't speak some form of Chinese. The ladies behind the counter spoke both Cantonese and Mandarin. My one complaint was that when I asked for extra sweet soy sauce for my zhaliang, the lady said it would cost extra. What. Serious? For soy sauce? C'mon.

Can I give half a bonus star? Well, this is my arbitrary system so I say I can. I would come back for the zhaliang, but probably a hard pass on everything else unless I'm really craving some cold dim sum.
author: Abby W.

description:
My friend and I were headed to a meeting one Saturday morning, and he wanted to stop by TC Pastry to pick up a couple dozen BBQ pork buns. I love discovering new places in the Sunset to get BBQ pork buns! We waltzed right in, and it must have been 7:30 in the morning. The place was nearly empty, as expected for that time of day. 

My friend ordered one dozen baked pork buns and one dozen steamed pork buns. They were fresh and ready to go in no time! I will say that these pork buns were quite tasty, but they were the smallest ones I've ever seen from any dim sum place or bakery. I cannot recall what the price difference was, but I would rather go somewhere else that has larger ones. 

However, I would not be able to resist if I was in the area. And I saw that they have fresh porridge here, which I was craving at the time. I would try this place at least once more before dismissing it as an option. The service is fast, and there is seating here in case you want to hang out.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Came across this nice authentic Hong Kong dim sum express. 

Curry fish ball- good texture and spice, boncing teeth!
Porridge - good thickness, tasty ingredient. 
Water chestnut -  rare find
Turnip Cake - spot on but ask for reheat.
author: Cal C.

description:
I come here for one thing only because TC Pastry does it extremely well:

Black Sesame Paste Dessert

Admittedly, I know very few people that would voluntarily consume what looks like a thick black paste/soup....but it's smooth, creamy, sweet, and just a tad bit smokey. Really delicious! Value-wise, you can get a quart sized cup for just a few dollars and it's enough to fill 4 bowls for my family.

Over the years, we've definitely tried a few other items varying from dim sum to steamed buns, but none have really dethroned other cafes/bakeries...perhaps because every family has its "list" of where to get what items.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Not quite the place for:
- Impressing bouge friends
- Dim sum date

Is definitely the place for:
- Cheap convenient take-out
- Bringing your out-of-town friends to, and making you look like a savvy local who knows better places than HK Lounge and Koi Palace
- Dim sum date if you're cozy and past the phase of courting exclusively in nice places

TC Pastry is a very hole-in-the-wall, down-to-earth little dim sim shop that serves staples including traditional dim sum, pastries, and congee. It's not some hidden gem with magical-secret-family-recipe delicacies, nor is it run-down and dirty (health score is 91). It is simply a standard house-made dim sum, tasting exactly as it should and definitely a notch up from the pre-made frozen dim sum you get at cafeterias. 

Their popular zhaliang (rice-noodle-wrapped-Chinese donut) looks deliicous and is definitely on my list. Otherwise, my biggest complaint is that most of the food is cold. I understand that baking the food all day under heat lamps/steamers may dry it out, but I think they should at least warm it up before serving it; otherwise it feels like eating leftovers that I took out of my fridge and was too lazy to heat it up.

It's one of the remaining few places in SF where food is affordable--very good value, such as $2 for 3 turnip cakes. TC is perfect for a meal or a snack, since everything comes in small dishes. Of note, it is served in in those paper boats so and looks like bad-ass authentic street food.
author: Edna C.

description:
Why do people think this place is the bomb??

The only thing fantastic here were the cilantro dumplings... Everything else was very standard like something you would get at a ranch 99 deli food area. 

The shrimp dumplings were good but were room temperature which is pretty gross.

And stay way from the zhongzhi - rice wrapped in bamboo leaves. Disgusting - rice smushed with salted egg.

The preserve egg congee was flavorless - needed salt ginger pepper and more favor.  

Brought it all home for the chickens. Not worth the calories and ultimately y satisfying.
author: Madison W.

description: They have the best beef rice rolls that you can get to go. I always get at least two orders when I come here! Great for a quick bite.
author: Jessica W.

description: What a treat!!! This a great place to grab a snack before or after the park. We tried 4 or 5 things and all were excellent. Plus the value cannot be beat.
author: Adam B.

description: Decent dim sum take out style with a good selection. This is where the locals go. Very busy and fresh. The service isn't always all smiles, but they're busy! I like the curry puffs, potstickers, mango pudding, and Chinese tamales (joong).
author: Kris F.

description:
2.5 stars!  I hate to be a Debbie-downer, but the dim sum at TC Pastry is not my cup of tea.  I can see how it is popular though.  There's always a line out the door and these are my guesses: a) there is no other dim sum take out place close by b) it's cheap c) the portions are big d) service is quick.  I suppose it can satisfy for a quick dim sum fix or if you're planning on carb loading, but don't get your hopes up too high on the quality.  I don't normally crave dim sum, but that's what I wanted after returning from a trip to Amsterdam.  Being in a hurry, I thought to just get take out on my way to run errands that morning.  

Yes, there was quite a line to the counter once inside.  I will comment that the actual space where you can eat is dirty.  There are a few tables if you opt to stay in but the place itself is not too appealing, so your best bet is take out.  That morning, we picked up an assortment of items including the pork/thousand year old egg porridge, custard buns, beef rice roll, chicken/bitter melon rice roll, shrimp rice roll, shrimp dumplings (ha-gow), and beef sui-mai.  Definitely "American" sized dim sum.  We spend about $20 and had 2 bags of food.  I will say that the porridge was the best, following the custard buns.  I did not like any of the rice rolls at all.  The rice noodle itself was so thick, greasy and chewy.  None of the fillings were adequate.  The meats were cheap and you mostly just get a bunch of thick plain rice rolls.  I thought the chicken/bitter melon flavor would be like the ones you get at a dim sum restaurant.  Wrong!  There was but one little piece of bitter melon and a few bits of mashed together ground chicken.  Ha-gow didn't seem that fresh as the shrimp was mushy.  The wrapper was also very thick.  I did not try the sui-mai, but the other half said it was filled with fatty meat.  

Overall, probably won't be going back.  I took a swing in the dark, and missed on this one.  Will need to actually go to a dim sum restaurant next time instead.  Parking is tough on Irving, so not really worth it for me to go through the trouble for TCP.
author: Liv A.

description:
I do not know a single place in the Bay Area that makes zhaliang (Chinese donut wrapped with rice noodles sprinkled with sesame seeds, dried shrimp, and shallots) as good as TC Pastry. They make them to order and in addition to the sweet soy sauce that I'm accustomed to having with zhaliang, they give you the option of adding peanut butter sauce. Friggin' orgasmic, folks.

The jumbo zongzi (glutinous rice stuffed with chestnuts, chicken, sausage, salted egg and steamed in a bamboo leaf) is also ridiculous. I was buying the ones from Guangdong BBQ across the street but the ones here are tastier. If you want to be healthier though I do recommend the one from Guangdong BBQ.

The majority of the other buns and dim sum items range from 2-3 stars for me. An hour before closing you can get 3 items for $1.45 which is a pretty good deal. It's cash only and the ladies are overall pleasant (not as nice as the ones over at Hing Wang, but nicer than at Happy Bakery). Solid option for fast food dim sum if you're in the area but worth a 30 min drive if you're craving authentic zhaliang for breakfast.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Let's hope we came on an off day but we discovered that the food went bad really quickly - perhaps a lack in quality of ingredients? Don't bother ordering the tofu dish under the heat lamp because it smelled funny almost immediately after we bought it. Also, the Cantonese guy helping out in the front almost scammed us (overcharged us $5) for an extra bag of cocktail buns before we checked the receipt and approached him about it. None of the bread in the front is fresh (they keep fresh bread warmed in the back) and the BBQ pork buns are an absolute miss. I'm for sure not coming back for this sub-standard dim sum and "accidental" attempt to scam my money.
author: Austin L.

description:
Pretty good stuff here.  Came by this weekend and picked up some dim sum and bao's to go.  Large selection and prices are pretty reasonable.  I'm not sure but I think they use MSG because I was so parched and did felt to lethargic after eating their food.

I had some Joong, pot stickers and Jah Luerng.

Will give it one more shot.
author: Henry S.

description: Not the cleanest place in the world and if you don't speak Cantonese or Mandarin, not so easy to figure out. But the food is okay and the prices cheap.  So I'm coming back. Not taking any woman here... Not a place to impress... But by myself or with construction worker or taxi driver types... Sure.
author: Leung T.

description:
What I ate: Assorted dim sum
Visit date: March 8, 2015
First time? Yes.

All kinds of dim sum here! My friend was I charge of getting three of everything for our party. She came back with a tray full of savories. One of my favorite dim sums is the fried taro. Unfortunately, TC's was a little on the greasy side to me. Instead of biting into a crisp shell, I got crunch and oil. Not so appetizing. I think it might have just sat too long by the time we got to it. The other dishes were more inviting. Also, I tried a couple of new items today. There was what I like to call a "tofu chicken sandwich." It was tofu stuffed with a chicken patty of sorts wrapped in tofu skin. There was also a mini omelette type patty with mixed veggies and pork. The salt was well balanced in the various dishes and sauces. I especially liked the dumpling with watercress and dipping it in their chili sauce.

There are a few tables inside, but most people ordered to-go. I'm curious about their rice porridge (we didn't get it this time because we didn't want to get full off of one dish); someone across the way got it and he made it look good.
author: Erin G.

description: TC Pastry is great for some dim sum treats. My review is mostly for the baked BBQ pork buns. These pork buns are some of the best I have EVER had. Most buns are mostly made of bread with little filling. TC Pastry is definitely not that way. The ratio of BBQ pork to bun is 50/50. If you're ever in the mood for the baked BBQ pork buns, I recommend TC Pastry!!
author: Monica Bianca B.

description: I wouldn't say I'm qualified for many things but when it comes to this dim sum shop, I've been eating here since over a decade. Friendly, fast and yummy. Over my last 10 years eating from here, I never got sick, I never left unhappy, they were like family. For fast & to-go dim sum, I give this a 5/5 stars because I know that a lot of new places popped up over the years. This place is one of a kind with a good track record.
author: Kay U.

description: Don't sleep on this place. Sound this gem when I was in college & everytime in the area I have to stop by & get me some of the shrimp & chives/ cilantro dim sum & Buns.
author: Angie C.

description: Solid dim sum.  I'm a fan of their rice roll with Chinese fried donut inside, reminds me of the Taiwanese version that is kind of hard to find in SF.  All their various dumplings are solid - lights, flavorful, and smell delicious.  Everything is a little bit on the expensive side, compared to Chinatown, but still reasonable.
author: Ben W.

description:
When we came in here, I thought it was kind of unsanitary just because there were a lot of things going on in the front of the restaurant. There was one table that just had meat on it. I looked over the menu and was intrigued more towards the fried food area, yum.

Eventually, I ordered 5 won tons for $1.55 + tax (because it was a closing special) and they were yummy!

Would love to come back here and try more of their food.
author: Aj C.

description:
One of the many cash only dim sum places in Inner Sunset/Richmond. There's a Wellsfargo bank 2 blocks away if you need an ATM.

Their dumplings and congee (pork and thousand year old egg) are pretty solid. I wasn't a fan of their tofu and pork dish though.

Everything here's pretty cheap so definitely a decent place to go if you're hungry and want to eat something fast.
author: Lily L.

description:
Not bad for take out dim sum...

shrimp noodles: too much noodle to shrimp ratio

Mini custard tarts (dan tat): not flakey but more like a cookie type crust. I enjoyed it and would order it again

Turnip cake: standard as any other place. It's basically a type of flour mixed and steamed. Can't go wrong.

The ladies here are nice and smiley
author: Liz N.

description: This is the best dim sum south of golden gate park. Their steamed gai bao, har Gao, Siu Mai are perfection. I also LOVE their turnip cakes. There's nothing here that I've tried that was disappointing. I've been eating here for more than 10 years. Check it out, you'll love it too !
author: Jim R.

description:
This is my go-to dim sum place when I'm in San Francisco! I've had other places, but I like this one due to the excellent taste and incredibly cheap prices. I've tried most things on the menu, and my favorites would be the har gow shumai, shrimp with thick rice noodles, and the noodles with fried chinese donut. Everything is so good though!! I like the texture of the noodles, and they are generous with the amount of meat/shrimp in each of the portions. 

Also, this isn't the most sanitary place and the service isn't spectacular (there's a lot of scrambling around while waiting in line) but the food definitely makes up for it. I've never had exceptionally rude business here, and I feel like they are just busy so with all of the customers that the service feels rushed. There's usually a line when I'm here in the mornings, but it moves very quickly due to their efficiency. There are also a few tables so that you can eat there if you wish or take everything to-go. 

Side note - I usually eat dim sum here and then go across the street to Happy Bakery to get chicken buns to go. Definitely a great combination!!
author: Aye K.

description:
I've been to TC Pastry twice now, and both times I left feeling satisfied. This is your typical dim sum shop located in outer sunset. Most of its items are average, but the one thing I keep coming back for is the BBQ pork turnover which is not something that is very common in your typical dim sum shop. It is so flaky, with just the right amount of char siu filling that is not too gooey and not too chunky. This place is very cheap, and surrounded by boba shops to finish your meal with. 

Overall, TC is a decent dim sum shop which has one item that I enjoy greatly and I will continue to stop by when in the area.
author: Mark O.

description:
Cheap take out dim sum place. Nothing fancy but not the best quality for dim sum. I'm not sure how good I should expect a take out place to be though.

Egg tart: 1/5 Do not get. The crust was not flaky at all and tasted like one piece of crunchy bread.

BBQ pork bun: 4/5 The only thing that was decent here. Filling was juicy with lots of flavor. Bread was a tad on the dry side.

Shrimp and chive dumpling: 3/5 Just okay, kind of on the greasy side

It's a good place to go if you want something quick and cheap but the only thing I would get here again is the BBQ pork bun.
author: Tanya Y.

description: I bought their yellow bean buns and mushroom & vegetable buns. The steamed bun was very soft, fresh, and thick. The yellow bean bun was smaller than the vegetable one. I think 3 of them equaled the size of 2 of the vegetable ones, but overall they were very fresh and delicious. All their assorted steamed buns are $2.30 for 3 or $0.80 each. I would definitely come here again. The workers here are really friendly, even when they are super busy! Service is fast, items are fresh, and food area is clean!
author: Celena C.

description: The tofu pudding is on point. No too sweet. Nice firm texture. Hella fast service. And you can't beat these prices. Be sure to tip!
author: Judy L.

description:
Quick Notes:
Good, but not the best
Dim sum for an affordable price. 
Cash Only
3 for ~$2.00

Ordered:
Shrimp and Chive
Beef
Curry Fried Won Tons

+The shrimp and chive dim sum was stuffed to my liking. Most dim sum Bakeries tend to skimp on the filling, but not TC Pastry. 

+The beef dim sum was tasty, but nothing out of the ordinary

+Curry fried won tons were delicious! However, the crispy won ton wrappers are ridiculously oily. I had to pat it down with a napkin and break the edges off, because it was definitely too much to swallow.

TC PASTRY, DIM SUM YUM!!!
author: Briana H.

description: Giving this place 2 stars because of poor customer service and cleanliness. The front desk and floor was covered in grease and crumbs. The lady at the front desk spoke little english and was not very friendly. Give the food a 3/5 stars-ordered the shrimp "crepe roll" and chicken pie. Ive had better dim sum in San Francisco
author: Michelle L.

description:
TC Pastry is a small shop located in the outer sunset district.  Our main goal going here was for the bao.  

One of the most frustrating thing about these places, or SF itself, is the parking.  Make sure you have plenty of time, and patience about the parking situation.

We purchased the BBQ buns, rice cakes, coconut covered balls with black beans, and sesame seed balls.

Their service was quick.  The gentleman that was there answered my questions regarding the regular buns vs the wheat buns.  

Overall, this is a good place to grab a quick bbq bun to eat.  I would return the next time that I go to SF.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Horrendous. In every way.  Unless u study iron-stomach Kung fu and are currently in training, avoid this place at all costs.  Super filthy as well.  Rusty fridge, boxes, total mess in the dining area. Proper dirty this place.  
And the new place right next door, just as bad.
author: Nick C.

description: Great place to come when you are craving Dim sum food.  I love how they have the black sesame dessert here.  I like coming here to get their congee and their chinese donut.  It's hard to find a place that makes good congee that does not have MSG.   The sesame ball here is good too and i like coming here to get that along with their steamed bbq pork buns.  I only like the white buns. You can usually spend 20 bucks here just on yourself.  I recommend you bring your own bag because you might think you are leaving with 1 or 2 items, but when you look around you want more and more.  I like the red bean pudding they have here, i don't know the English name,but you will always see the Stars eating it in the old TVB dramas.  If you come close to closing the items goes on sale! Bring cash!!
author: Belinda C.

description: The interior is a bit dirty.  Food was good. It was a bit cold even though I ate it in the shop instead of takeout. I ordered shrimp and chive shumai, shrimp and ciliantro shumai, and sesame ball for dessert. They were all good. But the sesame ball was particularly good~ I think about it time to time :) I would Togo next time and reheat it at my house.
author: Irene S.

description: In addition to everything that I mentioned a few years ago, I found they make my favorite dessert: bok tong go here and it's DELICIOUS! It's a sweet white rice cake in a triangle shape that's so light and fluffy and amazing. Other places make it thinner and harder, but this one is perfect and even tastes good a day later. I'm seriously considering ordering these for my wedding later this year if they sell in large quantities. It's that yummy.
author: Jenn D.

description: Cabbage on the floor, unknown liquid on top of the freezer and cardboard boxes as stepping mats. Those were the things you can find at this restaurant. The Chinese doughnut was very dense and oily. These things are are suppose to be light and fluffy! The egg tart were pretty good but oily as expected. My friend said her stomach felt a little queasy after. But the food was cheap! So I guess we don't have an iron stomach. If you do go ahead and take that risk!
author: Nika L.

description:
"Pastry" is the operative word as many of the items in the display case were either encased in pastry (little chicken pies, hot dogs in a pastry roll, cha siu bao) or deep fried. It was a little disappointing but buy I did after making the trek across the city.

They had a few pieces of steamed shrimp and cilantro dim sum which were outstanding: perfect wrapper, big chunks of shrimp, just the right balance of cilantro and garlic. I would go back for those in a New York minute. 

(They bumped up this review's star rating from 2.5 to 3 stars.)

But no beef balls, XLB, shiu Mai, ha gao. It seemed every time I asked for something I got a "no". Not, "we are out of this but try.," or "We have x but it's pork, not shrimp." Customer service was definitely lacking. 

For the items I left with, the cha siu bao were far too sweet. The bun was overly sugared and the BBQ pork inside, also sweet with no complement of savory flavor. I tossed half of it. The chicken potstickers, while over-sized, were simply "meh." 

The dan tat were just ok and seemed a day old or at least baked hours before and left at room temperature where they dried out in the display case.

So I'm still searching for my place where I can get cha siu bao and dan tat as good as Lung Fung bakery AND excellent steamed dim sum all in one place.

The pilgrimage continues..
author: Jennifer O.

description: best place for takeout dim sum!!!! no place compares. very fast and cheap. my favorite is the fun gwoa. definitely one of my comfort foods
author: Erica F.

description: They dont have names of the food next to its tray, language barrier, and since its so busy there isn't much time to think. Speaking the language might be helpful. I got an assortment  of potstickers, i liked the shrimp and chives ones, rest was mediocre and creasy. Also, they only take cash.
author: Tri S.

description:
Writing a review for this spot has totally slipped my mind. This little dim sum spot has been my go to spot lately. Especially since most spots close early or if you don't go early enough they run out of items. Also the prices are great here. 

I usually come here with my little sister. It's our usual Sunday date spot. She loves the mini egg tarts. I love the dry rice cake noodle thing (white thing with green onion you pour soy sauce over) and their shumai is so tasty! For less than ten bucks, we pick up lunch and have our little dim sum date. 

One last important thing: the people are very friendly. Service is always great. I always have lots of questions and they don't get annoyed of answering them. That's a plus in my book!
author: Dara S.

description:
The thought of dim sum to go is pretty intriguing, and that alone is a reason to show up. They are quick and there are tons of options.  

The place is very no frills and unassuming.  The dim sum itself ranges from just okay to pretty good. My favorite is the char siu bao (steamed pork buns).  Prices are so cheap you can load up on a ton of stuff, and try everything out. Virtually no dipping sauces though, just hot sauce and soy sauce.
author: Jeanne M.

description: Food Taste terrible ,i don't come back this restraurant  anymore,and place so dirty!!!
author: Wen Y.

description:
Haven't tried all the little dim sum joints out here yet, but TC Pastry is in the lead as my favorite one so far. I usually stop by after a weekend run to treat myself to a few pieces of somethin'. 

They have this TC Pastry-exclusive Chinese sausage bun (rice with sausage bits wrapped in a thin wonton skin) that I don't know the official name of and that I haven't found anywhere else. 

So cheap, so good. Alas, they don't take card. Sad times.
author: An Y.

description: Great place to grab an assortment of dim sum, including porridge, and they even have sweet tofu!
author: Jenny C.

description:
When I want to enjoy dim sum on the go, I normally hit up Mongkok on Noriega.  However, I recently discovered that there are several dim sum takeout places on Irving, which is much closer.  I found the best rated one, and decided to give it a try.

I ordered the BBQ pork buns, shrimp crepe noodles, pot stickers, and pork and chive dumplings.  I really enjoyed the pork and chive dumplings and the BBQ pork buns.  The noodles needed more soy sauce, and the pot stickers were way too big for my tastes.  Prices are awesome and everything is pretty much under $2, and the entire meal only cost $7.50.  For what it was, it was pretty good.

Service was pretty good and got us going pretty quickly.  I wish the food was actually served hotter despite coming out of the steamer or microwave.  There's lots of options for dim sum in the neighborhood so I'd probably check those out first before coming back here.  In a pinch though, totally decent for a fix.

Food: 6/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Super cheap dim sum in St Francis square. I think this is the only dim sum place in the immediate area. Good if you just need a snack!

Not a sit down type place (though they do have seats and tables), more meant for takeout. Some items are better than others.

========
We got:
Won ton soup: Meh. Had much better but to be fair this one had more won tons in it than anticipated.
Har gow: Meh, have had better again.
9-vegetable dumpling (uhh not sure what to call it exactly in English but it's the chives dumpling I think): It was REALLY good! Except super super oily, of course.
author: Emily C.

description: I've been traveling for the past year, and had a craving for some TC Pastry! I decided to pop in a few days ago (as they were closed for two weeks or so). I had regretted it pretty quickly. I ordered some chow mein and wontons, and some shrimp-cilantro dumplings. I'm almost 100% sure that there's MSG or lots of salt in the chow mein and wontons because I was feeling pretty sick afterwards. i will say that the price is downright awesome, but I'll stick to the dumplings and bao instead of anything that may potentially have lots of salt or MSG.
author: Evan K.

description:
Not my favorite go-to spot for dim-sum takeout, but it's pretty decent. 

Their shrimp dumplings are good, but Good Luck Dim Sum's are way better! I also had their crispy taro and they were ok.

Overall, 3.5 stars. The lady who helped me was actually really nice. I would come back!
author: Fallon P.

description:
i remember my eldest sister taking me here years ago when we shopped on Irving St.  I thought it was kind of odd that my sister would pass by so many dim sum places on irving just to get here to this obscure dim sum place which was so far away from most of the shops nearer 19th Ave.  Then i noticed why when I saw how UNIQUE a dim sum place this is.  Yes, other cheap dim sum places have the usual chinese donut, custard tarts, shrimp dumplings, sesame balls, etc., but TC has SO MANY OTHER dim sum that are tasty that I've never seen before.  For example, they serve very tasty savory curried pastry puffs with chicken or beef or bbq pork in a golden baked just right pastry.  They have dim sum with taro, etc. I and my sister like their food so much there that we can spend over $30 easily in one trip just to take home for later.

If it's behind the counter for a while, it may not be as fresh as it COULD be.  It's still ok to eat, but if you want REALLY FRESH, ask them you want it right out of the kitchen fresh.  I was surprised when I ate their shrimp/cilantro dumplings which were cold but ok tasting, but which were waaaay not as fresh than their long shrimp noodles which were so tender and hot straight from their steamers.  

There are only a few large tables and it's not really clean and scenic and it gets full in their shop quickly so I wouldn't spend that much time there to hang out like a starbucks.  There is no bathroom readily available.  Its definitely NOT a place for a date.  Most people take their food and then leave.  Some people stay to eat their dim sum for a few minutes before they leave.
author: Frugal C.

description:
I don't know what to say, this place is the ultimate. It's like any bakery, Chinese or not, with a glass display - but this one is full of DUMPLINGS. Delicious dumplings. And baked/steamed buns and pastries filled with both savory and sweet deliciousness. And for cheap - most things are like, 3 for $1.90.

I also like that this is NOT in Chinatown, so it's not crazy crowded and "touristy."

Favorites - shrimp + cilantro dumpling, potstickers, steamed egg custard bun.

That cilantro tho. It was bright and crunchy and perfect with the shrimp.

The potstickers, and the har gow pork dumpling, were Godzilla-sized. I'm used to those small bite-sized ones from the cart at dim sum restaurants - these were like three times the size and generous with the meat. UGH SO GOOD.

The egg custard bun I just ordered on a whim - I like egg tarts but was like hmm maybe? And it was hmm YES. The best way I can describe them is a steamed not-so-sweet donut with a sweet creamy egg custard filling. I dunno if that makes sense.

I did not much like the sesame balls, bc they were so damn greasy. Like, they oozed. The Chinese donut, which was seriously as big as a tyrannosaurus rex femur, was also a "can do without" - not too much flavor, a bit greasy, and not worth the stomach space. I'd rather eat a few more potstickers.
author: Jessie I.

description:
Tasty, tasty business. 

Been here a handful of times, and they never have flouted my personal pot-sticker standards. I am not Chinese, nor do I have any skills in cooking, but man, there's just something about their potstickers that makes me say "Wow. Now that's a potsticker." If you feel similarly, I highly recommend these glorious pouches of pork. The outside is soft where you want it soft, and browned and crispy where you want it browned and crispy. They seem to fall apart just at the right time, not when you bite into it and the other half sort of dangles indifferently from your gob. No! It breaks open seductively on your little dumpling plate and shows you its lovely juices and soft meaty interior.....Ahem, I digress. The potstickers are good. 

I always enjoy their shrimp dumplings, fried wontons, and pork dumplings. Next time I go I'll branch out and try some new things; last time I was enticed by their wonton soup but the will to consume a series of dumplings overpowered me. 

Minus a star for the slightly slovenly environment. It could use a bit of a refurbish. That said, Golden Gate Park is just a hop away, get in it and enjoy your dim sum picnic-like!
author: Chelsea B.

description: Good, fast and cheap way to get your dim sum fix. If you want you tiao (Chinese donuts) don't wait until the afternoon - they often run out.
author: Tina W.

description: Egg custard buns (lai wong bao) for only 75 cents each ! Cant beat that! Dim sum is not as authentic as restaurants but good enough for a quick dim sum to-go place! Service is decent too.
author: Victoria T.

description: This is my favorite place for dim sum. I love the deep fried curry puffs! I think about TC pastry way more often than I should. At least 3 times a week. They are closed on Tuesdays! So don't get your heart set on it on Tuesday like I always do. They are extremely inexpensive and also just the best food. I also live dangerously close to them, so I might be biased.
author: Anna M.

description: Who love dim sum look no further, everything is label. The food is so good here. I love it when I bring my own containers and they fill them up. I have a few other friends say this is a good place to teach you names, and what each item is.
author: Seaera T.

description:
Only four days after returning from my trip to China, I found myself driving slightly out of the way to pick up some cheap take-out dim sum for lunch. I just love dumplings and buns so much. CAN'T STOP WON'T STOP. 

I chose three things: shrimp, chive water chestnut dumplings (3 for $1.85), beef rice roll ($2.10), and pork buns (3 for $2).  I chose the dumplings based on the old Chinese lady ahead of me buying a ton. I figured she knew what to get here, even though instincts told me not to buy dumplings that were just sitting on a tray and not in a steamer.  The filling was good, but the skin of one dumpling was dry and hard. I guess I got stuck with an old one.  The rice roll was pretty thick. I like it. The best thing was definitely the steamed pork bun. The filling was delicious! While eating them, I thought about how happy and rich I'd be if I only ate those pork buns for breakfast lunch and dinner.  It's a shame they're not better for you. 

I wouldn't consider this place a destination by any means, but if you're in the neighborhood and want some cheap Chinese food, here's your place.
author: Jenn C.

description: The lady at the front, SUPER RUDE. Treats customers like shit. Place is run down. ONLY good thing, dim sum is dirt cheap.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Generally good quality dim sum for the low price, great tasting congee/porridge.  Taking it to-go is a better option than trying to eat at the store with limited utensils available and a constant draft blowing in.
author: Robert L.

description: this is only for the sweet rice cake and the service. This has got to be one of the nicest asian bakeries I have been to. The lady that helped me out was the complete opposite of rude and was so friendly. I got my hubs a order of sweet rice cake which was 3 slabs for $2.00. This is kinda pricy but the hubs loved it. He was like its just the right consistency and super soft because sometimes it tends to be dry on the end. He also got a fried dough stick which was hella oily per the usual but was a good crunch flavor.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: Tasty, affordable and quick dim sum. Perfect for a lazy weekend morning or afternoon. It can be hard to find a parking spot, but you don't need to put much time on the meter because getting in and out of TC Pastry is easy. We love to add their fried wontons and curry puffs to our order.
author: Annaliese D.

description:
This review is solely based on the customer service of the owner. 

I have been coming here for ages. I remember back in the days there was an old guy (I believed it's owner's father) sitting at the corner watching the operation of the store. The last two times I visited was a bit disturbance.

Incident 1: It was at the end of the day. They were selling dim sum at a discounted price. The old lady in front of me asked the owner (the bald guy) to microwave her food. The bald guy yelled at her "Go. Go. Go. Go away." Well, the owner could be a bit nicer. He could just tell the old lady microwave service was not available for discounted dim sum, but he chose to yell at her in front of others. Perhaps, next time I should shot a cell phone video.

Incident 2: It was the closing time again. The bald guy was cursing loudly at his kitchen staff in front of customers. This disturbed my nerve a bit. I just felt like I was shopping at a sweat shop.
author: J L.

description: 10/10 location, 10/10 food, 10/10 price 10/10 convenient location near boba and GG park. You know it's good when even white people come to this hole-in-the-wall. Also cool because the ladies won't make fun of you when you order in shitty Toisanese.
author: Cailin H.

description:
I've been visiting this place since the late 1990s.
I have had dim sum at some pretty fancy places, and some pretty divey places, but hands down, without a single doubt in my mind, this place has the best beef dumplings I have EVER HAD. 
The consistency. The bits of water chestnut. The seasoning. Even the bit of greasiness. It is all AMAZING. I would eat it every single day if I could. Every single day. 
I don't make it into the city often, but I did today, and I bought them out. The orders are, I dunno, like $1.70 for three. I got 7 orders of it. It won't last through tomorrow. 
I will weep bitter tears of paradise lost when I run out. Which will probably happen first thing in the morning.
author: Ev L.

description: Been going here on and off since 2005.  This place is a small store, nothing fancy for sure.  If you want dim sum with a fair price, then drop by.
author: Guest U.

description:
I really love coming to this Dim Sum joint, because I'm not treated like a second-class citizen! Everything here I've eaten has been fresh and delicious. My favorites include the Hargao (sweet shrimps and chives inside a rice wrapper with water chestnuts), Chicken or BBQ pork buns (delicious, hot, and filled with lots of fatless meaty goodness), Chinese donuts, chicken and veggie dumplings, and fried shrimp cakes. My boyfriend really likes their hot dog buns and combo buns here as well. 

If I was a super fatty (and I have been MANY times), I'll order three or four boxes to go that'll feed my family and friends. I really love that the ladies make everything here, and give you suggestions on things that they like to eat. I always tip these girls, because they are so fast and efficient when it comes to packing things up.  

I'll take chop sticks, thanks!! I'm happy you didn't just assume I wanted a fork! MORE PORRIDGE PLEASE!
author: Charlene S.

description: Stopped by for a mid-afternoon snack - this place is simple and fast, with a pretty extensive menu (printed in English and Chinese). The prices are pretty much unbeatable (3 for $2.50 for dumplings, or $0.80 each plus tax). I ordered the shrimp and chive dumpling (made from glutinous rice flour), and the taste was fine but it's evident that the taste is from use of MSG and a fair share of oil. The dumpling was quite cold and the glutinous rice was a little too thick for my liking. Overall, though, this is a pretty good place to grab some dim sum. Would be much better if the food were served warm though.
author: Michelle S.

description:
After a few meat-filled days, I was in the mood to go meatless. Their mushroom & veggie steamed bun hit the spot. It was delicious!

I also enjoyed their shrimp-chive-water chestnut dumpling and sesame ball. Their sesame ball was a bit greasy, yet had a nice sweetness to balance the savory in my meal.

In a recent visit, I tried their cocktail bun. Be sure to eat it while it's still warm. I made the mistake of letting it sit while I took care of errands and it tasted pasty cold.

Cash only.
author: Cathy K.

description: My best friend and I used to come here all the time when we lived in California for college. We LOVED  coming to get food here! We'd always leave with boxes full of goodies. Now whenever I'm visiting and near the Zoo or Ocean Beach, I always make a stop here. My faves are the shrimp & cilantro dumplings, the shrimp cake, the coconut balls, the spicy won tons, the shrimp or pork dim sum, etc...ugh so much to rave about. The place isn't fancy but we all know how little hole in the wall places sometimes produce great food. This holds true for TC Pastry. The prices are GREAT, the food is yummy, so if you're in the neighborhood stop in. ;)
author: Kanani K.

description: Cheap Asian dim sum to go. They have a lot to choose from and 90% of the stuff is good. Pork buns are small but they come in 3 and its around $2. Parents always gets the Chinese donut wrapped w/ rice noodles for my nephews. They only like this joint for that one particular item and know the difference if you get it somewhere else. Can't pull a fast one on them cuz they won't eat it.
author: Julie L.

description: This was always my place to visit when I go to SF. I ordered several different dim sums ($53)and it may be the last time I will come here. They have changed chefs or they are using inferior ingredients, but it is likely that the chef has changed. The Siu Mai was awful because it was not moist and little flavor, the har gow (shrimp dumplings) was not fresh and had more bamboo shoots than shrimp (very little shrimp), the chew Jhow dumplings had an unusual amount of preserved vegetables than pork, beef wrap rice sheet tenure changed and had little taste, the BBQ pork buns had less BBQ pork filling than normal, the deep fried rice balls with pork filling had unusual thick skin. I cannot recommend this place for dim sum.
author: K Q.

description: TC Pastry has the absolute best sesame seed balls I have ever eaten, and I try out such pastry wherever I go.  This place is the place to go in San Francisco for Dim Sum!
author: Bob P.

description: It's my go-to place to get some inexpensive dim-sum whenever I come into town. My usual take is about 1 doz. steamed pork buns, 1 doz. custard buns, about 6 pcs each of various dim sum pastries and whatever my kids and I have a mood for. I take them home to freeze and pull them out whenever we have a craving. I'd re-steam them since microwaving would mess up the pastries. Sure, the front/dining room area may not look sparkling clean but this place is not a 5-star restaurant. I've been to some nice dim sum restaurants and you're paying for the privilege to be served. There was one dim sum restaurant that I thought was nice that I took my kids to for some dim sum, saw there was some black flakes in one of the dim sum bamboo steamers.. I looked closely and it had tiny legs. It was steamed ants in the dim sim. Told the head waiter. Head waiter looked at the dim sim, picked up the bits that had the ants, smooshed it onto my daughter's plate and comped only that particular dim sim plate and ordered a new one for us. Gross. A few minutes later, there was a distinct odor of Black Flag coming from the kitchen area. We haven't gone back there and that restaurant is no longer there. So you really can't tell a book from its cover. Dim sum making is becoming a lost skill since not many people wants to do something so tedious. It takes a lot of patience to make those things.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Great place to go for a quick take out.

I love their noodle wrapped Chinese donut 

Chicken turnovers are so good too

Everything else is pretty good too
author: Carol Y.

description: It's super cheap. It's tasty. The bbq pork buns are legit. The shrimp dumplings are respectable. You can fill up on a few bucks. No reason not to go here.
author: Sean B.

description: I had been wanting to try this place for a very long time. Finally walked over last week and got all types of shrimp dumplings, steamed pork buns and sesame balls. I may be spoiled since I've lived in SF my whole life and have had the chance to try dim sum from all over the city but unfortunately this place wasn't as great as I had expected based on the Yelp reviews. My favorite dim sum place which has the best shrimp dumplings I've ever had are at a hole in the wall place on Noriega. Sesame balls were pretty good though.
author: Sosse M.

description:
During the last hour of opening each day, they sell most items at 3 for $1.30, or at a discounted price!

Spicy wontons (WINNER!!), sesame balls filled with red bean or mung bean, pork buns.. you can mix & match and easily try tons of different options and get full for less than $5. This will for sure be one of my go-to places for lazy nights that I don't feel like making dinner, especially since it's literally around the corner! That being said, I wouldn't consider it a place you'd travel to, but it's great if you're already in the Sunset area and are looking for cheap goods.

It definitely does not have the most aesthetically pleasing interior, but still.. what a hidden gem this place is!
author: Andrew T.

description:
What?! 3 pieces of delicious Dim Sum for under $2?!  That's what I'm talkin' about!

Though, I didn't really care too much for the potstickers.

This place is pretty small, not really the dine-in type - more like a grab & go.  They have a pretty good variety of dim sum, and because the price is so cheap, you can really afford to try a few different ones. My faves were the steamed dumplings with shrimp or chicken.
author: Shamina K.

description:
Why drive all the way to Chinatown for take out quality dim sum when you live in the Sunset?  T C Pastry is good enough.  The price is right.  Food is tasty.  Service is polite and efficient.  I haven't found a better place this side of Golden Gate Park.

I buy enough steamed items for 3 meals.  They freeze very well.  The fried curry bun is my favorite.

The sticky rice cake (nien gau) is delicious.  It is only available at Chinese New Year.
author: Debbie T.

description:
Let me say that I've had a lot of dim sum in my lifetime... 

And this is a place you want to go! Cheap and good!

I always buy to go, and take it to the beach or golden gate park. It's not the nicest place to eat but they do have tables if you want to stay. 

Everything here has been pretty well made. I don't think I disliked anything. And I love the fact that $14 of dim sum will stuff my boyfriend and I, where as if you go to an actualy restaurant, it will cost around 30 for the same amount of food

Favorite items:
-Siu mai = pork dumpling
-Deep fried won ton (curry flavored, so good! but a lil greasy)
-Bbq pork buns - or any steamed buns. 


Just remembered... I would skip on the steamed rice noodle rolls, its a lot of dough.. 

Anyways, I am so glad they have a 2nd location in daly city! and it is just as good. :D
author: Erica L.

description:
This place is what it is. For what it is, it gets 5 stars. I downgrade to 4 so that there is at least some semblance of continuity across the review spectrum. But the bottom line is - if you're looking for hong kong flower lounge, don't come here. This place gets 1 star on the flower lounge scale. 

But this gets 5 stars on the "I just want some take-out dim sum without the hassle of long lines/mobs, fancy dim sum experience" scale. 

I like to come in here on a Sunday and just chow down. I don't order all at one time (b/c they have a problem here keeping food warm, no question), I order a little of this, a little of that...they have great diversity of menu choices and great prices, so you get to try a lot of stuff.

My #1 favorite here is the duck egg porridge. Man that is good. I get a large every time. 

their dumplings are excellent. I particularly like the 'Fun Gor" I think it's called (meat, chives and peanuts) and the mixed veggie/shrimp dumpling. 

Their buns are ok. Too doughy for my taste, but the fillings are good. I like their Chinese sausage bun, not too often that I can get some straight-up, whole Chinese sausage. 

The curry dim sum is fine, the spicy wontons being the best of that bunch. I don't get out of there without chowing at least a few of those down.

As reported elsewhere, their potstickers are solid. their rice noodle rolls are not that great. The noodle is just too bland and does not get sufficiently compensated for with sauce and filling.

their lotus leaf sticky rice is not the best I've had, but not terrible. In fact I somewhat prefer their fried rice ball instead, that's pretty good.

Biggest complaint about this place - lack of sufficient beverage choices. It's disappointing when I go to a Chinese take-out kind of place and they got a bunch of soda bottles in the refrigerator but no plain iced green tea. No worries though, in this neighborhood a tea joint is never far away and in fact there is one on the same block. So I stop by there to pick up an XL green tea before I go into TC Pastry
author: Ravi S.

description: While on Irving Street, this is definitely my go-to dim sum place!  Overall, I thought the consistency of this restaurant is pretty good and I love their selection.  This place definitely gets the job done whenever I am craving dim sum.  Keep in mind that I am very picky with my dim sum, so this place is proved to be very good!  What I also love about this place is that I can stop by and get my favorite pork and preserved egg porridge.  I love how this pace has plenty of the egg and pork in there (some places are actually pretty stingy with this).  I've had other porridge that taste completely of MSG (YUCK!).  But thankfully, this place isn't one of them!
author: Teresa W.

description: Best value on the boulevard (i.e., Irving Street).  Friendly staff.  Had the hai gow, thought at end of the day the skins were thick and hardened.  Also, bbg baked bun--and that was good.
author: Thom S.

description:
Came here on a gloomy day with the SO because we weren't trying to find a real dim sum restaurant but more of a cafe-style type of dimsum so that we could relax a little (do we sound like an old couple? It could definitely get worse.)

Everything we ordered, ranging from the steamed items (shu mai, har gow, lotus leaf wrapped rice) to the fried items (dumplings, fried breads etc.), I don't really have anything for. I would say price point is cheaper than a dim sum restaurant but not particularly that cheap in general (I know, it's hard to please an Oakland native with SF prices).

Parking is also not the best of the best in this area (yep. Can't stop making the comparison to Oakland's parking to SF's) but you can always pay for metered parking (even on Sundays).

The place is pretty laid-back and nothing too special. I would say, order some food, relax and chill but this is definitely nowhere close to the best dim sum I've ever had...
author: Winè C.

description:
As much as I love this place since it's opening, I have to think twice about its cleanliness.
It happened twice with this female employee constantly scratching her head and wipe her nose with her hand. She was handling the take out dim sum with her bare hands no gloves.
I would give the dim sum 4 stars but the sanitary condition 1 star.
I wish the owner give some in-house staff food handling safety lessons before someone get food poisoning.
author: Cocoa W.

description:
A small dim sum shop with just about any dim sum/Chinese snacks you could want.  They have a case to the left, a case in front and several yellow printed signs all over to give you the prices.  Some of the things I tried:

Mini egg tarts (4 for $1.50): these don't really have much filling because they're so small; but they are a nice little sweet treat.
Egg rolls (3 for $2): these are fried to a little bit darker than golden brown.  They are crispy and pretty big.  They definitely have a good amount of grease to them; but if you don't mind that, then they are pretty decent.
Steamed buns (3 for $2): I like that you can mix and match.  Options include bbq pork, egg custard, chinese sausage, veggie, etc.  They are kind of skimpy with the fillings, but the flavor is okay.  The bun itself is nice because it is not overcooked nor dry.

They have a couple small tables, but I think most people take it to-go.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Cheap! Get there during the last hour and everything is half off, extra cheap.

Spicy wontons and sticky rice balls are my goto.
author: Matt K.

description:
Good food. 
Fantastic prices.
Cash only.

We recommend the BBQ pork buns, shrimp + cilantro dumplings, and egg custard. Ate at one of the four, four-person tables. Soy sauce, chili sauce, and plastic forks available. Everything was sticky. We loved it.
author: Marbu J.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite spots on Irving! 

I love their jook ($1.50 for a small?!!), their custard buns, fried curry wontons, pot stickers (though I do recommend you to bring it home to microwave them bc they're not hot.. ever), curry puffs.... basically everything with the exception of the har gows. The har gow skin is just too chewy and thick for me! 

Keep in mind, this is primarily a take out dim sum spot, so nothing is really going to be as hot as a sit down restaurant!

If you go early enough in the day, you might be able to catch their ja lern (chinese donut wrapped with rice roll skin). It sooo yummy, but make sure you get both sauces!
author: Tiffany U.

description:
The best shrimp dumplings here. I also tried the BBQ pork bun which was good but a bit too fatty for me. The sesame balls were yummy too. BBQ pork buns run out fast so earlier in the day is best. 
All orders come with 3 pieces and under $2. You can get your Buddha belly full of good food and still have dessert. It's very filling.
author: San C.

description:
A solid 4.

Limited selection, but relatively fresh, and cheap to boot.

No place really to sit unless you want to hide in back.
author: Rafael S.

description:
Yay cheap, one block from my office, and ready to address my hangovers with lots of shrimp and water chestnuts.

Not huge on thier zhong ze (delighfully labeled as rice pork tamale!) thought it was a little too mushy.
author: Misha T.

description: TC Pastry is a no frills place to get cheap dim sum. All you have to do is order at the counter, pay and then take a seat at one of there few tables. The people working there don't know English too well, but there is a menu and you can point to what you want. I really enjoyed the sticky rice w/ meat wrapped in banana leaf, beef noodles, shrimp dumplings and pork bun. You can easily get dim sum for two for under $15. Great place for an easy, quick and cheap dim sum experience.
author: Hanhie D.

description:
Our order: baked pork buns, shrimp dumplings, beef dumplings, egg custards, sesame balls, steamed buns (chinese sausage and chicken & veggie).

My recommendation: go for the dumplings and shu mai, but everything else is not worth it.  The bonus is that we had so much food for a ridiculously cheap price.
author: J J.

description:
I bought their egg tart, wife cake, little chicken cookies, etc. They came warm and look very good, they have a lot of traditional HK dim sum that i can't find elsewhere, such as the sticky rice bun, i haven't tried them yet but I feel happy looking at them:)

Another I came to buy their Chinese donut. My god. It's the best one I've had since 14 years ago back in Canton! I am so happy to find such a good one here!!!i also bought radish cake, water chestnut cake, rice noodle with bitter melon and chicken, coconut bun.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I think it's the best dim sum place in the mid-Sunset area. The baked BBQ pork buns, egg tarts, HK milk tea and stuffed tofu are my favorites. 

Still haven't figured out what TC means, except that it might allude to "Tuesday Closed".
author: Kevin N.

description:
For the price, this was great, but there are better dim sums in Chinatown at the same price. The chicken pot pie was too sweet for me, the Shrimp crepe roll was not that good.

Other than those, the Wonton soup was really good! I bet there are other really good things on their menu and I will go back and try some of them.
author: Charles Z.

description:
I got the steamed mushroom bun and shrimp & cilantro dumplings. Both were great although the bun had a little less filling than expected and the shrimp dumplings were a little greasy on the outside.

Best part was the service: I let them know about my nut allergy and the woman told me what I could and could not get. After she started to pull out the steamed dumplings I asked for she turned around and told me that she wanted to be careful because everything was prepared separately but steamed together. She helped me choose another option based on how things were prepared and stored.

Although it's not quite as good as Sunset Bakery, I was incredibly appreciative of the extra mile they went to ensure my food was nut-free.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Yummy Yummy!
Fried Curry Wontons: So good! It's actually really filling, so one order (1 order = 5 wontons) is just right for one person. Too much fried stuff is not good for you anyways.
Curry Fish Balls: I just wish they add more curry sauce.
Egg Custards: It's good, but personally I like the mini ones more.
Veggie and mushroom bun (?): The flavor of the mushroom. LOL but l wish that the filling is mixed better. One bit is of mushrooms and the other is of radish, so inconsistent. but I like that they slice the mushroom, other places they just put the whole mushroom in the bun. 

The last time I went they had rice dumplings (zong zi), I had the meat one. I normally dont like eating them, but since I haven't had any for a while, I thought I'll try theirs. I like it. But it may be a tiny bit too salty for some people.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
I had been coming here ever since I can remember. Once cannot tell by looking at the building, but this was the best place to get dim sum. I would be still coming here if it wasn't for the parking issue.

But the owners did open another shop in the Richmond near Washington  H.S. When I walked into Jook Time, it was just the few staff I knew from TC Pastry.
author: M C.

description: Good dim sum!  The ladies were friendly.  The shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive were delicious.  Will come again.
author: M S.

description:
The cocktail and hot dog buns were not very good. The cocktail buns seemed on the burnt side and the hot dog in their hot dog bun was the worst hot dog I've ever eaten. 
We did order other items like their spicy won ton which was tasty and the mini custard tart. 
Would I go back ? NO.  There are better places in San Francisco.
author: Bush L.

description: Yummy dim sum. My new favorite take out dim sum place. The "spicy won tons" are delicious. Bits of meat, curry flavor, deep fried in a wonton skin. Yum!
