Chicken turnovers were kinda like a mochi skin filled with meat and sauce and then deep fried. Trust me. It is better than it sounds! This was my first time, but will definitely be back.
author: Sharon T.

description:
Good dim sum,, but nothing out of the ordinary.

Ordered: Pork, shrimp and fried post stickers
Taste: smooth and with no chunks of gristle or fat
Flavor: minimal, but none of the greasy film you get with sub-par dim sum
Amount: 3 per order
Cost: $0.50 - $1.20 per order.
After effects: no tummy or bathroom spashbacks ;0)

Dessert: egg tarts (mini) 
Taste: sweet, smooth and with flaky crusts
Flavor: good taste and liked the little bite sized cups
Amount: 3 per order
Cost: $1.20 per order.
After effects: wanted more =0)
author: Jai D.

description:
They have everything. I've tried so many different things here, and it's all pretty good --har gow (shrimp dumpling), siu mai, turnip cake, sticky rice, sesame balls, etc. They have a lot of other things like soup, pork buns, etc, etc, but I haven't tried those. 

Staff seem friendly. Everytime I've come here, the crowd is different... sometimes I'm the only customer, sometimes there are a few in front of me, and once around Chinese New Year there was quite a line. Either way, they get through everyone's orders pretty quickly and efficiently. Prices are decent!
author: Lani S.

description:
Although the prices were cheap (togo-type-of restaurant), I must've came on an off day b/c I thought the dim sum was fair.

Ordered:
1) Shu mai: 2/5--had better (tasted like pot sticker meat)
2) pot sticker: 2/5 okay too...
3) Egg tart: 3.5/5: surprisingly good!
4) Chive and shrimp dumpling: 2/5

Probably won't be back. We decided to sit down and eat there, but the place was freezing. Our dim sum was cold after 1 minute of opening the container. I was a little disappointed after reading all the raves from yelp. =(
author: Jen H.

description:
3.5 Stars. I'm not quite a fan but I would go here if in the area.
They offer very cheap Take Out "Jook" AKA Congee and Wonton soup.
Their baked Cha Siu Baos were alittle odd cuz they minis.( not full size ).
I think they were 3 for $1.80. Seems like everything was 3 for $1.80.

All I know is I bought more than enough food for 3 adults for around $18.
author: Winston W.

description:
I live close by and whenever I crave for dim sum, I come here!
Reasonably priced and taste great! Portions are good and fast customer service.
Parking is a pain on Irving so try to drop someone off to order for you. Closest thing to Chinatown quality but not in Chinatown haha.
author: John Z.

description:
Preface: I'm white so bear with me.

TC pastry, on the surface, is your normal rundown/dirty dim sum joint offering fresh and juicy (see: greasy) dim sum at minimal cost with a side of judgmental stares for your white ass. 
To be honest, you really can't go wrong with anything. What is that dumpling contraption with shrimp? Who knows, go for it. Is that a shard of glass in my pot sticker? Yolo. 

The review is solely based on two things: the baked pork bun and the chicken pie.

The baked pork bun gives victors a solid run for its money. Victors is better size wise but is a little pricier whereas TC's baked pork buns are a solid mix of sweet and salty; the bun is in a sweet bun with perfectly seasoned bbq pork tickling all taste buds leaving your mind blown (and pocket happy @ 3 for $1.70? wuttttt?!). don't want 3 pork buns? Suck it up and bask in the carb-y salty/sweet goodness my friends. It's been a rough week in the office and your significant other is cheating on you, you deserve it.

Chicken pie: have you woken up in the middle of the night, sweating your ass off begging for a chicken pot pie? ME TOO! If you say no, you're un-American and a liar. Every time I hear someone say "chicken pot pie" I get happy three times and so should you. So you rush on over to your nearest safeway, tear open the freezer doors and you stare Marie calendar dead in the eyes as she is about to feel defeat as your craving will be satisfied. And then it happens: half way through your indulgence you're just tired of the chicken/pea/carrot/bread combo and toss the rest and do the walk of shame back to bed. Here is the beautiful balance TC pastry offers:  A CHICKEN POT PIE THAT FITS IN THE PALM OF YOUR HAND. Boom, that just happened. After one orgasmic bite, you feel the love that chicken pot pies give you, the consistency you deserve and a serving size that tickles every craving your belly can work up. best part, SWEET BREAD. TC pastry has mastered the sweet/salty and for this I am grateful, and so should you.

Side notes: all of the other dim sum is good. Standard, but nothing to write home about.

But for god sake, do yourself a favor and scrounge up $3 and step into pastry heaven. Or step across the street to happy bakery and have explosive diarrhea, the choice is yours. this is your dynasty.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I'm guessing this is the same TC Pastry as the one in Daly City.  This is a "take-out" type of dim sum joint. It's small inside but comfortable - there are a few tables, if you decide to eat here.  

Their dim sum is pretty darn good - plenty to choose from and prices are great!!  On this visit we got shrimp rice rolls, beef rice rolls, shrimp/cilantro dumpling, BBQ buns.  Everything was around $1.90 for 3 pieces.

My favorite of 'em all is the Sticky Rice Ball w/ Chinese Sausage. Holy Moly that was good!! I usually see sticky rice wrapped in banana leaf but this yummy rice was wrapped as a dumpling...say what!? I am now a fan of this unique creation!!
author: jesiree b.

description: Best sweet fresh Asian rice cakes! Also water chestnut cakes are amazing!! I always go by for those two staples
author: Jocy V.

description:
Of all the cheap dim sums I've been to in the Sunset and the Richmond this is the second best, next to Good Luck Dim Sum.

Other cheap dim sums die out by 1pm. The dumplings become greasy, the pastries harden, it's a fat Asian kid'ss nightmare. TC Pastry's dim sum tastes somewhat fresh any time I go. Even at 4pm, the meat dim sums are still good.

It's $1.60 for 3 of their main meat dim sum which includes various dumplings and shumais. It's similarly cheap for any of their pastries. I've had nearly everything they sell and never had a problem.

Here's a menu I found with a quick google search: http://dineries.com/ca/sanfrancisco/tcpastry/2222irvingst .

That doesn't include everything though! They also have larger items, refrigerated items, and some in a buffet style steel pan. I've had their wonton soup; It was simple, yet good. Chicken broth, scallions, and 4-5 sizable wontons. I've also had their mango pudding. This was a first for me and it tastes exactly as it sounds, which is good a thing. I look forward in trying their Durian pudding next. I haven't had anything from the buffet pan but I once saw tofu with chicken inside of it. Suck it vegetarians!

My favorite items are the fun guo dumpling, barbecue pork turnover (the filling of barbecue pork bun in puff pastry) , chicken pie, and shrimp rice noodle.

This is the kind of place which I wish I lived near my entire life. A place where I can go at any time of day and get my fill of dumplings, fresh pastries, fruit pudding, and hot soup. All under $3.
author: Rahil P.

description:
BEST DIM SUM IN ALL OF SAN FRANCISCO I CAN ONLY SAY THIS IN ALL CAPS APPARENTLY ITS THAT GOOD.

There I was, another obnoxious New York transplant in San Francisco, crying every night over the lack of cheap and fantastic dim sum on the west coast... yeah sure, San Francisco has the biggest chinatown around, but their restaurants had become touristy, and the food just "OK." And then, like a vision on a flaming pie, it came to me through the prophetic mouth of my roommate- "T C Pastry... go there my sonimeandaughter" 
And I did.
And it was good.

Huge range of fantastic tasting dim sum for no more than $1.25, including my all time favorite dim sum ever- rice balls! RICE BALLS THE SIZE OF MY FIST. Oh, it was good. And now that I am back in New York, I find myself pining away for the wonders that was T C Pastry... alas, alack, such is the roller coaster of pain we call life.
author: Jenna I.

description:
Good Dim Sum. The insides tastes and  feels fresh. It's not all mushy on the inside like many and the dough is thin enough, not to think. 

I like the insidse better then Good Luck dim sum on Clement. But the dough is a little thinner at Good Luck.

I'll be back.
author: Anthony M.

description:
We stumbled upon this place while on a quest to find one of my fondest childhood comfort foods, Bak Tong Gou (White Sugar Sponge Cake). We drove down Irving, confident that we would find at least one dim sum restaurant serving it, and sure enough, we found TC Pastry. This place is the proverbial hole-in-the-wall Chinese takeout joint. We had no idea whether the food here was good or even safe to eat, but they had Bak Tong Gou, and that was reason enough for us to pick some up. We bought 2 orders of it, 3 pieces each, for less than $2 an order. What a deal! Better yet, it was every bit as good as the ones in Shanghai. They were moist, soft, chewy, and mildly sweet. Craving satisfied. I did not have a chance to try the other dim sum, but all of it looked fresh and appetizing. 

Recommended: 

Bak Tong Gou
author: Jenny C.

description:
Not the best dim sum for being in sf but it wasn't horrible.

Prices are relatively cheap.  The mini egg custards are alright, leave you thirsty.  The deep fried curry bun didn't taste like what I was expecting (I've had it elsewhere before).  The traditional hot dog buns were good, and I also enjoyed the sticky rice balls with chinese sausage in them.  

I spent less than $5 and had enough for left overs.  If in the area it wouldn't hurt to stop by.
author: Belinda T.

description: Went there hoping to get their cha leong but was sold out. Sigh. Got their fish and peanuts congee, and it was good with big pieces of fish. Got a fried doughnut to go with the congee and it was yummy. Got some dumplings too. Would go again but distance is bit of a problem for me!
author: Ris N.

description:
Cheap Dim Sum anyone? 

I would have never found this gem if I didn't wander the teeny-bopper walking,  Asian gangster car leaning, and old man spitting streets of Irving. This place is no BS. Order in the front, get your food and stuff your face within minutes.

Thank you, my boy Stanley for visiting. Good Friends. Good Food. Good Times.

Everything is under $2 - Holler!
author: Dorian T.

description: Price is great, service is good however I have had better fried Taro dumpling, Shrimp dumpling and siumai.  They also serve hot entrees and congee as well but I didn't try them. Its also CASH only. I would definitely try the other good dimsum place with 4 starts just around the corner:)
author: Claudine V.

description: Very good, and I would recommend it if you are in the area, but not quite up to Good Mong Kok Bakery.  I had a variety of dumplings and buns and enjoyed them all - their chicken, pork, and beef dumplings were all very well done and flavorful, but I thought the shrimp dumplings were a little too cheuy and the bun was a little doughy.  There are about 4 or 5 tables though to be able to sit with friends, and they are also very cheap - 2 people can easily get out of there for $10.
author: Jesse F.

description:
I've been to Yank Sing and other Chinatown Dim Sum places and I always think, "This is good but why am I paying over 4 times more for 3 pieces when I can get just as good at T&C?"

Anyway, T&C is great because you go up tot he counter, point at things and pack it all up for you. They ask for $9 and you think, 'Wow, that's cheap!" Then they hand you a bag overflowing with dim sum that could feed a small country. Also, as its namesake states, this place truly is a dim sum "specialist". 

I'm glad I live a few blocks away because I love grabbing lunch that only costs me $4.
author: Rylan C.

description:
While on Irving the other day, my friend decided to take me to TC to stop by and grab some snacks before heading back to his house. When we first got there and saw the prices, I was surprised at how inexpensive it was. We went pretty late in the afternoon, so most of the items were gone, but we did get some Rice Noodle Roll w/Shrimp, Turnip Cake, and Egg Custard Tarts. I believe everything was around 3 for $1.50. Then what surprised me again was that the dim sum was pretty good - even considering it was probably not so fresh, and we didn't eat it until an hour later back at home.

I kinda wanna come back and try everything while fresh. Seeing a small place like this to grab good tasting and cheap dim sum is kind of all new to me - growing up in the 'burbs, I'm used to going to the all out restaurants, so this was pretty cool.
author: Tiffany K.

description: I kept hearing about this place. I finally came by after being in the area. Since the other dim sum place up the street yelp reviews said they had steamed roach with their food. I stopped going there. Anyways back to TC Pastry,  I ordered pork and shrimp dumpling, potstickers and a chicken pot pie.  It was cold, dry, and did not have any flavor.  Definitely not coming back!  Two stars for cheap prices and cleaner bakery than most downtown area bakeries.
author: Diana L.

description: This place is as bare-bones as it gets. Great food purchased at a counter with short wait times. Don't expect anything but huge volumes of cheap dumplings that are among the best you've ever had at five times the price.
author: Michael K.

description: I love their jook! It's pretty cheap, $2 for small, $3 for large. I rather have the large portion than small, its only a dollar difference! I love coming here for that only and their egg tarts!
author: Sandy C.

description:
I'm generally not that picky when it comes to dumplings, so naturally, I like this place. It's tasty, cheap and parking isn't too difficult.

If you have a mix of sweet and savory, make sure to ask for them to be packed separately, or else your hargao and siumai will be rubbing all up against your sesame balls.
author: Amy D.

description:
My parents brought over a batch of dim sum.  TC Pastry still strikes me as cheap and average but one item was very good (it's my mum's favorite): steamed mushroom buns.  They're small and the dough part is just okay but the filling is excellent with juicy, large slices of more than one kind of mushroom, celery and carrots.   

The steamed chicken buns continue to be just okay.  The steamed cake was too dense and tough.  You can tell just by looking at it that the texture is wrong.  The sheng jiao bao isn't filled with juicy pork but it has this mixture of ground meat, water chestnuts and things you'd normally find in the hom suey gok (deep fried savory cousins to the sesame balls). The curried beef turnover didn't have a flaky crust/shell.  You could tell that it was wrong just by looking at it.  

Get the mushroom buns and the red bean mochi (if you don't mind the coconut).
author: Lolia S.

description:
When out in the avenues, sometimes we get hungry, this place will do just fine. 

We usually get baked pork buns, hot dog buns, and sometimes siu mai.  The buns are not too large, maybe about the size of a baseball and filled nearly all the way with meat goodness.  Two will do more than satisfy for a snack.  The hot dog buns are always a hit.  18 of them, a few hot dog buns and a few pieces of shrimp dumplings ran less than $18.
The siu mai was just OK and I have had a lot better, but 3 of them for just few dollars is a good deal.

Not much on atmosphere, most things are to-go.  Bring cash.
author: Michael M.

description: way better service than Good Luck dim sum on clement!!  I wished TC pastry was on clement.  But I have to admit, not everything here is good. I like the chicken su mai, shrimp & chives dumpling and that chicken with egg thing. I forgot the exact name of it. The pot stickers were nasty. Other than that, everything else was decent. Great service too!
author: Alyce l.

description: What's not to like about quick, cheap dim sum? Super quick service on a Federal Holiday.
author: Anne T.

description:
Crap.
It all tastes like well-seasoned fecal matter.  The to-go box was literally a little kiddie pool of grease.  Like, don't get me wrong, some extra greasy dim sum isn't necessarily a bad thing, unless you're at this place.

The luke-warm siu mai can easily slide down your throat with all the lubricant on it, the har gow is in the same throat/boat, deep fried taro root wasn't that bad, and the cha siu bow was pretty sub-standard--small+mediocre, shit filling.
Crap.

Pricing was actually all kinds of cheap.

Story time:
So, some friends and I each got a bunch of random stuff (see above) to share and try the variety of dim sum they got.  After about 5 dumplings and a jigger of minutes, the lethargy set in, eyes got weighed down with grease, mind activity came to a screeching halt, and the need for someone to invent a bed-toilet were all present.  Then ''the rumble.''  The horrid, horrid rumble down below.  Who knew har gow could be so explosive?iCrap
author: Gar Y.

description: I've been coming here for over 15 years and this dim sum joint still hits the spot.  Although I speak the language, this place derves 5 starts because they speak the best English and they also have signs in English.  The owner and staff are always very friendly (not rude) and to top off it off, she said "take care" on my recent visit!   That alone deserves 10 stars!
author: MeLuvCookie M.

description: Love the dim sum here! Been coming here for a few years. The noodle rolls with beef or shrimp are really good. The noodle is a bit thicker than other places, but I like it! One order is usually pretty filling if you end up getting other stuff. The bbq pork bun is good, egg yolk bun... bomb... the siu mai and hai gao is good here too. The porridge here is piping hot, it's not like other places that sit around and look disgusting. I think it's cause a lot of people order from here so they are constantly making new batches of it. Like I said though, everything here is tasty and definitely worth trying if you're in the area or if you don't feel like having your traditional dim sum at a dim sum house with tea.
author: Johnson S.

description: I went there twice, i think it is worth to try! They provide a lot of Dim Sum, it tastes really good.
author: Yuerong G.

description:
If you're in the mood to pig out and have a few bucks, why not go here? Sure, it's not the prettiest of all places, but hay the food is good. Actually, from the outside it looks a little sketchy, as in super dark, half covered up with papers posters cardboards etc, and you cant really tell wether or not it's open.

So in conclusion,
Yay for food
Nay for environment (but who the hell cares about environment when all you want to do is pig out?)
author: Jessie C.

description: This place is a low-budget wonder. I'm obsessed with their curry puffs and spicy wontons. If you're in the area and are looking for something quick and togo, this is the place you need to go for cheap dim sum. I usually stop by here before heading to a park to hang out just because the food is so easy to take along and it's SO good.
author: Jasmine P.

description:
i'm LIKING the new remodel here. Looks nicer than how it looked before.

The service is slower though than before and they keep running out of har gows when i come here...

also their prices slightly went up!
author: Kenny L.

description:
Is the place dirty? Yes
Is it cheap? Yes
Does it look like a dump? Yes
Is the dim sum good? Oh Yeah!

If you are one of those judgmental types that can't stand things old cardboard boxes as the rain mat and beat up tables and chairs just keep walking. But it you like good dim sum and have ever seen how similar restaurants in Asia look, then this place is for you.  

My latest discovery here is the chicken turnover.  Give it a try and you won't be disappointed.  The heart attack inducing Chinese donut is pretty darn good too but make sure you hit the gym later to burn off that grease.

Most of the menu is prices for 3 items but they will let you get individual pieces if you ask.
author: amul s.

description: Hands down best dim sum in SF. Hai gow with water chestnuts ftw
author: Tim O.

description:
This is the way dim sum should be:  delicious, cheap, and easy to get in and out quickly to pick it up!!  

TC Pastry has all of the usual dim sum suspects, and do them well:  their egg custards are the most flavorful I've had in San Francisco, and their shrimp cilantro dumplings are divine!  The pork buns are perfect in meat-to-bun proportion, and the chicken pot pies combine veggies with a strange-yet-delicious sweetness!

You can easily get enough to feed a family of four for under $10, which is remarkable in this day and age, and everything I've tried here is delicious!  If I had to count a downside to this place, I'd say it's that it is tiny, lacks any real ambiance, and the linoleum floors are a little depressing, but it's a bakery, not a four-star bistro, so you come here to pick up items for take out, not really to eat in (although they do have a few tables should you care to).

In a neighborhood where there are lots of places to pick up dim sum, this place is by far the tastiest, least expensive, and best culinary option!
author: Amy L.

description:
This is like the dunkin donuts of dim sum. Super fast and actually pretty tasty. 

Now the quality of the building is horrendous and the workers want you in and out fast in what seems to be a recurring theme here on Irving. The dumplings were great but in my opinion a bit oily. 

I liked the cilantro shrimp dumplings!
author: Jess E.

description: I am a white guy married to a Chinese woman.  I know Asian food.  This place has amazing snacks!  If you are lucky enough to be there when a fresh batch of curried wontons comes out of the cooker, you are in for a treat.  The food is great and the people are nice as well.
author: Tom B.

description:
WOAH. I never thought dim sum from to-go places could be so good! Dim sum was my favorite cuisine growing up and I only ever went to restaurants. I tried to-go dim once before but made the mistake of taking it home and microwaving it for dinner. This time I ordered 3 dumplings, sat down, and ate it right there. YES! I'VE FOUND GOOD DIM SUM! I got a ha gow, deep fried taro dumpling, and a pan fried chive and shrimp dumpling. The ha gow was amazing (and way better that yank sing!). It had big pieces of whole shrimp and water chestnuts. So. Amazing. The taro was delicious and was one of my favorites before I became vegetarian. Unlike yank sing, the chicken is in the middle of the dumpling and not mixed into the taro and could be easily avoided. I still love the taro dumpling and it was delicious here. The fried chive and shrimp had a thick skin which i wasn't terribly found of (think a steamed bun with 1/2 the thickness, then pan fried), but the shrimp and chives had a very nice flavor.  
I chose 3 different items and it came to $2.10 although 3 pieces of ha gow or shrimp and chive are $1.60 and the taro was something like $1. 80. I'm not sure how she calculated it, but its a better deal to get 3 of the same
author: Alice R.

description:
This is truly a bomb dim sum place, it is a typical hole in the wall that can easily be passed up, but it is hands-down a hotspot for authentic dim sum! I have come here for years and will keep coming back!

Why does TC deserve 5 stars? (my first 5 star review by the way)

-Quality, authentic, tasty, freshly made dim sum..in summary

-Fairly wide selection...most of it is displayed at the counter so even if you do not know how to order in chinese, you can pretty much point to it
      ---a few items that I like and recommend:
                 --the fried, curry flavored wontons are one of my favorite  
                 items there....they are quite popular...may be a bit on     
                  the oily side, but a must try :P

                  -curry fish balls
        
                  -sesame dessert soup

                  -chicken 'siu mai' (I know most of you traditionally eat the  
                   pork or even beef siu mai...but this is definitely a nice  
                   alternative for those who prefer chicken meat like me!)

                   -rice crepes (shrimp, beef, chicken/bitter melon, and
                    vegetable/mushroom stuffed are available....even though
                    I am not a fan of beef, it tastes the best here)

-And it's CHEAP!! You can squeeze in like 3 different dim items for about $5...definitely a deal you don't find in many places! And don't forget, the dim sum is GOOOOD! 

-The staff is pretty friendly and quick...beware the line can be long during lunch hour, but it moves smoothly

A few things to keep in mind:

-Parking is street metered and since this place is located centrally in the "chinatown area" of the SF Sunset district, you may have to make several rounds before finding a spot

-This place is best for to-go orders/quick snack because there are a limited number of seats and the tables are not always clean

--Stop by here and you won't regret it! 5 stars all the way!!
author: Wendy T.

description:
fast service, cheap and good dimsum! On the go food, and they open early at 7am, if you come right before they close at 7pm, the dimsum is discounted

Usually 3 pieces for 1.50! Better than eating at restaurants
author: Quyen T.

description:
Lately I've been getting into the habit of taking long walks.  Well, semi-long walks.  And this little dim sum place that could is maybe about a mile or so from where I live.  Thus how I justify my consumption of little dumplings of goodness.  And don't get me started on their sticky rice in lotus leaf.  No, really, don't get me started because I won't stop ooh-aah-ing.

Hands down the best chinese donut I've ever had in my entire life.
author: Yohanna B.

description: Visiting San Francisco with my kids and wanted to have some dim sum without actually going to Chinatown. Relying on Yelp for most dining options available, we decided to come here after visiting the Golden Gate park. We were pleasantly surprised to see all the offerings on this strip, but stuck to getting our dim sum fix at TCP. The staff were very nice and patient while we tried to make good decisions that would not render our kids thinking we were nuts and going overboard trying to satisfy our cravings. Try to understand- we live in Kingsland, Georgia....we have no access to good Chinese food nearby....not good when you grow up eating excellent food from all different cuisines. We were quite pleased after we filled five hungry tummies for $20!! I don't remember  the names of what we ate, but they were All good! We will be coming here again when we visit the city in the future!
author: Eleanor C.

description: 3.5 stars.  This is a bit of a dive with very bare bones tables, so it's better for take out.  But it was super cheap and quick to order a bunch of dim sum to go, including rice noodles with shrimp, vegetable dumplings, turnip cake, and especially the yummy chiu chow fun guo (chiu chow style dumplings with peanuts).  Altogether it was $11.  Wish I had this close to work - I'd be a regular.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Whenever I'm in Sunset, I come here for a quick snack. They have dim sum - the usual dumplings. They offer chow mein, porridge, and some buns on the side.  But I come here for the black sesame soup. I always pick up a large since I eat half now and save half for later. I like how they make the black sesame soup, they grind sesame very fine and they put just the right amount of sugar. 

There are a few chairs and tables for folks to sit down. But most of the time I just do take out.
author: Candace F.

description:
Probably the best dim sum in the sunset.
I always order the pork dumplings and the won ton soup, you can't go wrong.
For the price and service go here instead of going to happy bakery.
author: Corey W.

description:
It was getting to be afternoon & so the boy & I had to go around trying to find breakfast food @ different places.  We tried to go to Sun Maxim because of all the good reviews but it was under construction.  We finally ended up here & were glad to find the abundance of food choices available.

In total, we got 4 Cocktail buns, 3 Lotus seed paste buns, 3 BBQ pork buns with oyster sauce, 2 Put chai ko (bowl-sized sticky rice pudding), & 1 portion of steamed Sponge cake.  The cocktail buns had really good egg flavor & the filling was not too sweet.  The put chai kos' were too tough & they had a strong coconut flavor which I was not used to.  The BBQ pork buns were mediocre & the incorporation of oyster sauce was not as weird as we thought.  The sponge cake was my favorite; it was nice & spongy but not too sweet.  It was oily for some reason though.

Overall, the items were pretty good & for very reasonable prices too.  I am not sure about other places on Irving that sell baos, but unless otherwise convinced, this is going to be my go-to place for now.
author: Karen S.

description:
After devouring these coconut mochi balls with red bean filling every time they show up at my friend's house, I decided to find the place that makes them.  Therefore, my review is only based off these mochi balls! 

I haven't these from anywhere else.  The sticky mochi part is moist, soft and flavorful. Kinda like an egg-custardy taste to it.  I can't quite tell.  The red bean filling isn't smooth, but a little chunky.  Believe me, I don't like coconut shavings or chunky red bean paste, and these mochi balls rock my socks (when I'm not wearing Tom's).  I will definitely try out their other dim sum offerings next time.  There isn't any seating, so I guess you'll have to nom your food at home.  

Like I say to my best friend, "Yum yum in the yum"
author: Lisa X.

description:
With all the rave reviews about this place and being convenient to boot, my brother and I decided to give it a try.  We got there about 1130 and is wasn't too busy.  It is true the servers seemed bored, but they were efficient.  There was a strange looking guy in the back drinking some tea and later a can of Coke staring out at the customers.  Maybe he was making sure that the servers were giving out any freebies.

We ordered our standard of a couple of steam pork buns, hom fun (sort of a rice roll), chive dumplings, pork siu mai, har gow, and something that I can't remember.  The price per three items was about $1.75 - no super bargain since Happy Bakery across the street charges about $1.50 for similar.  We were going to eat our lunch there so they gave us a plastic tray and the dim sum was in a flop top plastic container (like a sandwich container).  We got our own plastic forks and started to chow down.

The food was cold!. I don't mean luke warm, it was cold. Even though we told them that we were eating in, they didn't bother heating it up for us.  Soon the line got a little longer and we didn't feel like asking them to warm it up for us.  If we did, we probably would have received the evil eye.  It was tasty, except the pork buns were not too good.  They charge extra for tea.  Additionally, they charge sales tax when most dim sum places like this already include the tax with the price.

The interior is typical of Chinese to go places - a little dirty and greasy.  If it weren't for the cold food, I might give it 3 stars, but their cavalier attitude deserves 2 stars.
author: Robert J.

description: They have simple, cheap, delicious dim sum options.  Whenever I'm in the area, I make sure I grab the cilantro shrimp dumplings and mushroom and vegetable steamed buns.  A yummy snack quick snack!  I docked a star because they do microwave your dim sum when you eat there.
author: Coffiend K.

description:
One of the better dim sum bakeries in the sunset. My mom who is a expert in shopping for the best quality dim sum gives this place her recommendation. The prices are good and the food though a bit too oily for my taste is still delicious. 

My favorite foods here is the turnip cake, har gow(shrimp dumplings), siu mai( pork dumplings), and the Nigh won bao (custard bun).
author: Jude N.

description: Been coming here for years. Fav things to get is the baked bbq pork buns, the best. Such tiny little guys are packed with so much pork and flavor, and at 3 for $1.60 that's a steal :) I also love the "ja lerng" or the rice noodle with chinese donut, sooo good. Good place to grab some food on the go and for cheap! They always get mad at my uncle when he visits SF, because he wants over 100 bbq pork buns, and they scramble to make them asap.
author: Vanessa K.

description: TC is now on our chicken (gai) bun rotation since my daughter is addicted to them.  Very inexpensive.  Two dozen of them plus six of the curry beef buns (the chinese piroshkis) came out to around $21.00!  This is one of the cheapest places around with the best variety.
author: Glenn L.

description:
Seriously, I'm not exactly sure what the hype about this place is.  I guess if you're stuck in Outer Sunset and can't get to Chinatown, then maybe, maybe this place will satisfy your craving.  But really, I would encourage anyone with a true craving to spend the time and effort to go out to Chinatown where you can find really 5 star places like Good Mong Kok Bakery and Golden Gate Bakery. 

I've eaten at a lot of Dim Sum places, and I have to say TC Pastry was only a "Meh" in my opinion.

Bottomline - if you have a craving and are at UCSF or Golden Gate Park, then this is your place.  But I can't say it was "mind blowing."
author: E C.

description: I'm pretty sure the food is good here. But I came in, and the lady is nice. We ordered some pastry and I guess she didn't here us correctly and got something else. When we told her that's not what we said. She got all butt hurt and said softly in Chinese that we don't know how to order and other stuff. Which was totally unnecessary. Then grabbed the money out of my hand and that's it.
author: M L.

description: Simple, unpretentious place with yummy dim sum, the taro dumplings and chicken cilantro dumplings are great. Be forewarned - cash only.
author: M S.

description:
OMG *angels singing* because the best dim sum shop in SF (yeah, it's not in chinatown. actually, there is NO good dim sum in chinatown... how disappointing. I have searched high and low and TC is TB - THE BEST!)

After 6pm, end of day sale - items on top of the counter behind a sign that says "3 for $1.20"! 

whatever they didn't sell that they are willing to sell for a cheaper price - today's TC pastry haul consisted of 3 sesame balls, 3 turnip cakes, 6 potstickers, 3 fried taro puffs, 4 fried won tons = $7! what? it'd usually be about... $11-$12? 

But it doesn't matter what you get - everything is delicious and fresh! Wish the guy in front of me hadn't snagged the last of their drool-worthy shrimp and chive dumplings... =*( AND he got them at a discount... damn, that doubly hurts!

yayerrrr!! I'm gonna be there every night at 6 and be the first! - except Tuesdays because they're closed.

And I'm only sharing this with you because I'm a nice person..hmph!
author: Christine C.

description:
Every time I'm around lower Irving I have to stop by and get some of their deep fried spicy wontons. They're like my favorite medium for curry flavor-to-mouth delivery *w* Sometimes I buy some and intend to take some home to my family but end up eating them all by myself...Eh heh...
Other notable things are their preserved egg and pork porridge, the turnip cakes, the sticky rice balls, the buckwheat raisin mantao, the black sesame woo, and the boot jaih goh. Cheap and delicious :3
author: Skye L.

description:
can't believe i still haven't  reviewed this place after multiple trips of gluttony on many a ravenous weekend morn. i feel like a failure.

eh no. no, it's more than that.

i feel like a....bsian. fo' shame.

come here and take your pick of various types of bite-sized deliciousness! deep-fried, pan-fried, steamed, curried...try everything and all, get your go-to favorites and try that dumpling or dessert you haven't yet already. for such an incredibly affordable price, you will be feastin' beast-status.

sure, the har gau (har gow, ha gao, badass shrimp dumplings, morsels of yum? whatever you call them) sometimes have their skins too thick and chewy, the deep fried wonton skin things (5 pieces for a $1 or some spectacular deal of the sort) sometimes a little too oily, the chicken shu mai sometimes too gamey-tasting not in the best of ways

BUT

for the so-low, you-be-in-minor-shellshock-for-a-wee-bit-as-you-hand-over-only-half-the-amount-you-were-initially-expecting-to-fork-out, got-damn-that-be-a-sign-to-get-three-more-orders-of-that-BOMB-DIGGITY-CURRY-PUFF-WITH-THE-SWEETISH-FRIED-DOUGH-THAT-COMPLEMENTS-PERFECTLY-THE-SAVORINESS-OF-THE-POTATO-FILLING-MMMMMMMM-SO-BOSS, kind of price you're paying for the amount of food you're getting, there really shouldn't be too much complaining about the little flaws hurr and thurr.

and get here in the AM/AM-ish when things are freshly made, if you get dim sum cravings at 4.30pm and come here expecting the freshest of dumplings with perfectly translucent skin...come on, now.

PS: MANGO PUDDING AND/OR DURIAN PUDDING IN THEIR FRIDGE FOR DESSERT. HOLY MOLY IN THE NAME OF ALL THINGS PERFECT AND COLD AND FRESH AND WOBBLY AND HIGHLY AROMATIC!!11111!!!!!!!!!!!!!11 MEGA DESSERT WIN. real mango pieces and real durian flesh pulp. whoaaaaaa! the mango pudding perfumes your entire mouth, and the durian pudding stinks up your entire soul, and in both cases, your taste buds and tummy rejoice with passion.

cash only. wear eating pants during consumption. eat with love. knock the fuck out after. sunday made perfect.
author: Eliza D.

description: Love this place. When I think of grabbing something quick to eat, I think of this place. Their wonton soup (without noodle) is my fav. Pork turnover, Curry fried wonton, Egg rolls, Cocktail buns, etc etc. And usually towards closing time, they would put their pastry/dim sum on sale (3 for $1.20). Note: They closed on Tuesdays.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
t.c. seems to have been around awhile. the paint doesn't seem that shiny.  almost all the items are labeled in english with the prices attached. they even have chinese tamales (2.10) and congee (2ish)

samplings:
-chicken bun (.65) white meat mixed with a little veggie good sized texture not juicy. bun not fluffy  but not too doughy.
-siu mai:(3/1,60) tender, chewy pork, not juicy.
-har gow(3/1,60) whole and partial shrimp with crunchiness provided by bits of waterchestnuts and the shrimps themselves. 

leftovers
-tax charged
-lots of msg used
-not soo busy.
-some seats availble for sitdown.
-friendly service
author: Victor G.

description:
Oh the choices of Dim Sum! Jook, buns and anything deep-fried! This is way better than Happy Bakery across the street for it's quality! My new found discovery is the Milk Tea here. Small cup of really strong tea that makes my large coffee want to spill itself over! Plus, the tea is cheaper! 

I don't know where to start with the food since just about all of them are tasty! I've tried their baked char siew paus, steamed char siew paus, deep fried taro balls and curry buns. It's definitely worth a try or two!

The thing to know about TC is that they are closed on Tuesdays. As a matter of fact, don't be surprised if you find them closed on other days.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
You can get full off of $1.90. 

Be ready to order because the ladies behind the counter don't like to dilly dally. 

Sticky rice "bun"
Custard bun
Cocktail bun
Chicken bun
author: Jacquee P.

description: The sesame balls are the only thing I get from here, because it is so delishous! Therefor, My rating is only for the fried sweet sesame balls. The sesame balls are always fesh and right out of the fryer! When I hold the sesame ball in my hand, it is perfectly round and when I bite into it -the good layer of the wrapping crunches a little but is also chewy and mixes with right amount of sweet mung bean ( I think it's mung bean, I am not sure) paste - for the best sesame ball ever! Yum!
author: Shirley M.

description:
Delicious take out dim sum!  Even good cold the morning after.  

I'd recommend nearly everything.  Here's what I Like in order of preference and may this help you pick out your pieces if you aren't sure what to get! 
- shrimp w/ cilantro 
- chiang fun (rice noodle): either plain w/ dried shrimp. with shrimp, or with beef
- sesame balls 
- wo tip (potstickers): these have a nice ginger taste in them
- "chicken turnover": best when eaten right away bc it's still crispy!  
- curry wontons
- cha siu bao/bbq pork bun
- chicken/pork ( i forget which) bao/bun.  it's white.  You can stick this in the oven if you have leftovers at home and the oven will warm it up as well as give it a nice crispy outside.  

Mmmm.  I've never had a problem finding parking on this block but it probably varies by time of day.  

There are a few tables inside if you care to eat there.  

If you're going to take out an order of like 25 buns, call ahead... a woman before me took all the buns in the morning before I could get any :( 

And I think this place is cash only. 

Oh and these people work hard...I see them early in the morning and in the evenings working together.  Pretty awesome.
author: Alias A.

description:
I decided to come back here after reading some reviews about how good their steamed mushroom buns are. ($0.70 each or 3/$1.80)  Few years back, I used to come here for the 4-pack wheat buns ($1.80) cause it was filling and I felt like I was eating something healthy for breakfast although it was purely flour/carbohydrates.

So... a couple days ago, I went with my friend to grab something light to eat here cause I had a craving for a Chinese bow. My friend was probably annoyed with me cause I kept on saying "DUDE. What should I get?" I kept looking at the faded yellow menu above me, scanning back up and down trying to figure out what to order. Everything sounded so good and all the little delicacies behind the glass windows looked so tempting as well.

After a few minutes (but felt like half a hour), I told myself I had to try a mushroom bun. I paid my seventy cents and couldn't wait to eat it. However, I was a little bit disappointed. I guess I had my hopes up too high about how delicious it would be. Instead, it was just average. The mushrooms were mushrooms and the bow was just a bow.

After finishing it, I started to crave for a BBQ pork bun. And my breath stank of mushrooms. Thank god my friend had a pack of tic-tacs in her purse.
author: Annie S.

description:
Dim sum from TC Pastry is never so good as on a Monday night (the day before they are closed for 24 long, long hours).

Home of the best sesame ball in San Francisco! 

We've been going here since I was a kid -my family goes here regularly for the pork buns (steamed & baked), curry puffs, coconut balls, hot dog buns, siu mai, shrimp noodles and oh; don't forget the little spicy puff thingies. I usually pass on the pot stickers, but the rest of the family loves them.

Mmm... time for a trip to Irving Street.
author: Wendy M.

description:
Really tasty, fresh, cheap dim sum in the Sunset. You can stuff a family of four for less than $40, and still have leftovers. I only wish it were closer to my house, as we tend to do take-out. The ambience is a little...spartan.

Remember, it's cash only.
author: T H.

description:
Yumyumyum. 

Cheap, fast and GOOD! 
I order the dried shrimp roll (65 cents), and the turnip cake (3 for 1.60) My husband loves the other dim sum specialties here, but I'm a plain jane with simple pleasures.
author: Alice E.

description: This is some of the best take-out dim sum we've had in SF-- better than the much-touted Good Luck on Clement.  And it's so cheap!  We had three kinds of steamed buns, pork, mushroom and vegetable, and chicken.  They were all good.  The pork filling is kind of cinnamon-y, which is interesting.  The shrimp and cilantro dumplings were super-good, very fresh tasting and with the perfect amount of cilantro.  The egg custards were also great.  This is definitely our new favorite place to grab dim sum and picnic in the park.  Highly-recommended.
author: Heather G.

description: I've been coming to this dim sum pastry shop for a very long time now and it's one of the better dim sum bakeries in San Francisco.  For a to-go and hole-in-the wall, they have real good har gow (shrimp dumplings) and also their steam pork buns are good sized and have more meat in them than other bakeries.  Most of their steam dumplings have pretty good flavor.  It's been one of my all-time favorite places to buy some dim sum snacks especially here in the Sunset district.
author: Arlene Z.

description:
TC Pastry, another no non-sense hole in the wall. Indication? 4 Yelps in a year and a half. This is no. 5. To a certain extent, TC Pastry is such a well kept secret, I don't want to be one to blow it up. 

Pres. Obama has asked us to serve our community, so on this historic day in American history, this is my message...

Like others have mentioned, yes, the dim sum is very good at TC Pastry. Leek and shrimp dumplings are hot, egg rolls are light & crispy, noodles are fresh, and a perfectly fried chicken stuffed tofu. 

Where TC Pastry separates itself from Mongkok Dim Sum or Happy Bakery is the HK style street style items...curry fish ball on a stick (in the morning!), Chinese donut wrapped with noodles with peanut sauce,  hot sesame dessert, and boot jai go (in Cantonese) just to name a few items to look forward to.  

The service will never blow you away, neither will the unkept tables and chairs, paper signs, and hand drawn pictures. This is simply a place that focuses on what matters, consistently quality food at the best kept dim sum & more in SF.
author: simon l.

description:
This place is a bit in the boonies, but it's hands down my favorite place for take out dim sum. They have every type of bun imaginable, and it''s super cheap - I don't even think a normal person would be able to eat more than $5 worth of food there in one sitting! 

Also, in the late afternoon, they discount their dim sum selections even further, for super penny pinchers. 

I love their yellow bean buns, steamed pork buns, bbq pork buns, sesame buns...mmm probably going there for lunch today so I can try different ones too :)

Note: they only have 2 or 3 tables - it's really set up as a take-out place.
author: Amy S.

description:
TC is my go-to dim sum craving soother. We've gotten into a habit of stopping by to pick up lunch after my daughter's swim class. Solid dim sum, maybe not the best of the best, but a fine option.

The variety is not as robust as, say, Yank Sing, but the standards are there: steamed bbq pork buns, shrimp dumplings, siew mai, the rice noodles with various fillings that come with the tricked out soy sauce that you drizzle on top, egg custard tarts, and sticky rice wrapped in the lotus leaves - my favorite. The kidlet likes the hot dog bun. And an assortment of Vitasoy brand drinks in the fridge? check.

Inexpensive and filling, and you're able to bring it home and kick it without having to deal with the insanity of the weekend dim sum excursion. We dig.
author: amy p.

description:
Their dim sum is so tasty and cheap that it is mind-blowing.  My mind literally explodes everytime I eat there.  I'm not exaggerating. 

I can attest to the other reviews of this restaurant that their dim sum is cheap.  I'm talking $1.50 for jook.  That's insane! (insanely good) My favorite item is 3 deep fried taro pork  for $1.69!  

If you get there past noon or near closing, don't expect the dimsum to be super fresh.  But it'll still taste great.  The best time to go here (as w/ all dim sum restaurants) is in the morning...get it freshly made.  

Their staff is very friendly.

FYI while this is a restaurant, it is more of a "take-out" restaurant that happens to have a few tables w/ seats.  They have Vitasoy and all that good stuff (drinks) that makes the dim sum eating experience amazing.  

I wouldn't go anywhere else for Dim Sum. Period.
author: Michael S.

description: Whenever I make it up to SF, a stop at this place is a must! Everything I've ever had here is so good, don't let the microwaves fool you! Not to mention their cheap cheap prices. I've yet to find somewhere in LA that rivals this place for Dim Sum takeout.
author: Elisa P.

description:
The steamed pork buns are pretty good. We buy a dozen and then freeze them and when we want a bun, just pop it in the microwave to defrost and then steam it and voila, a fresh pork bun!

The size of the bun is average and the bun itself is light, fluffy and squishy. There's a good amount of meat and sauce inside and the pork is in small pieces and soft. The sauce is thick and rich with flavor. There's a good ratio between bun and meat/sauce.

Service is quick and efficient with some pushing in line. All standards in Chinese take out places. It's a quick stop for some Chinese pastries without venturing all the way to Chinatown.
author: Janel Y.

description: if you like the pork dumplings...this place is by far the best in the bay in my opinion.  Even better than good luck dimsum in the richmond area.. also they have the egg cakes filled with bamboo shoots and water chestnuts that i love sooo much.  their other location in daly city is just as good....they also serve taho with boba! yumm..Their noodle dishes are ok at best but you come here for the hot fresh from the steamer dumplings! 4/5 judochops...do i have pork between my teeth?
author: Dustin G.

description: Curry puff, chicken & bitter melon, siu mai, pork turnovers, shrimp & chive dumplings, turnip cake, curry wontons, shrimp cakes, and other assorted delights. Tie off and shoot it because this fix is cheap.
author: Corinna K.

description:
Pretty good dim sum, super cheap.  I am, unfortunately, on an endless search for the perfect BBQ pork bun, and after being here, my search continues.  They were fine, but it was a kind of thin and gummy filling and too sweet.  The shrimp and chive dumplings were very big, but mostly filled with chives and less shrimp.  
They do, however, have a huge selection and you can fill up for around $5.
author: Jessica L.

description:
There are just so many dim sum places on this stretch of Irving, you kinda get lost.

Luckily, we've found T&C - really, really, really good dim sum - I'd almost bring visitors here instead of Yank Sing.

Prices are low, which is even better. 

I have yet to try the soups or the jook (brings back awful childhood memories) - but they look good. The lo mein is good - you can taste that the noodles are freshly made.

I'm kinda glad we don't live nearby, as we'd be here all the time. (Especially with TuttiMelon a few doors down.)
author: Kelly R.

description: Ahhhhh, TC Pastry! I've been going here for the past 3 years almost! One thing that I really like about TC Pastry that it (most of the time) remains consistent when it comes to food and prices! Some of my favorite to get are the spicy won tons, shrimp chives dumplings, and the BBQ pork buns! I love it when I get lucky and the pastries are still hot. I happily recommend this place to any friend in the area.
author: Angelo M.

description: I loveee this dim sum place. When I lived in the city, I would come here every week or so to buy lunch. The food is insanely cheap and I can buy everything I need to keep me full for under $5. It definitely doesn't have the nicest atmosphere but honestly who cares? The best time to come is right when they open because the food is very fresh and the potstickers taste way better than normally.
author: Clara D.

description: Well since Happy Dim Sum was out of custard tarts, I went here. I asked for it and they said, "You want small dan tat?" (custard) So I looked at it.. It was sooooooo tiny lol! You can get 4 tiny custard tarts for $1.15. So I got one and supplemented it with a coconut (COCONUT!!!!!!!) red bean ball. Yummy. Both were delicious. And the total price was $.85, less than the price of one regular custard tart at many other bakeries.
author: O K.

description:
Awesome place to go for a quick bite.

Things I love at this place: fried BBQ pork buns, friend curry buns and hot dog rolls. 

Prices are cheap and the food great.  Can't go wrong with that combination.
author: Serge S.

description: Subpar dimsum, expensive prices (compared to Richmond dim sum and chinatown dim sum), basically only come here if you dont have the 5 minutes to drive over to inner richmond. The har gow has really thick skin. The siu mai wasnt too bad. The buns were just awful. Definitely would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Kevin L.

description: We were tired of the Dim Sum take out places on Clement Street and decided to head over to Irving Street instead.  We found TC Pastry on Yelp and decided to try them out.  TC Pastry is great!  The place is small, a little older, but very clean and accommodating.  Their baked pork buns taste fantastic.  They are smaller sized too (and so is the price) which is perfect for us.  My daughter loved their hot dog buns and pot stickers.  Their custard tarts and fried spicy won tons were also excellent.  We had 4 small plastic bags of assorted dim sum for under $9.00.  Everything tasted great!
author: Chris F.

description:
This place is all kinds of awesome. It is, hands down, the best cheap Dim Sum I've ever had . . . it's better than anywhere that's cheaper, and cheaper than anywhere that's better.

We can feed 5 people here for under $40 easily, and have plenty of leftovers. I especially recommend their beef dumplings with ginger. Yum!

PLUS, hey, the close proximity to Golden Gate Park is pretty much custom designed for a picnic! Every year we hit this place before the the SF Comedy Day, and load up on munchies. We've not been disappointed yet!
author: Joshua C.

description:
My favorite "no frills", "take out" dim sum.
Their curry won tons and "puffs" are out of control.
Engorge yourself for 5 bucks.
Feed you and 9 of your friends for 20 bucks.
Honorable mention for their baked cha siu bau and their chicken siu mai.
author: Barry A.

description:
For: A Pork Bun by Any Other Name

On my quest to explore every pork bun, I decided to start my investigation in my own back yard.  TCP, which is just down the street from me, offers some tasty-looking treats that loc's seem to love.  As much as I wanted to try everything, I was just there for one thing: a baked pork bun.

Upon seeing them, I was astounded at how small they were; about 3 - 3.5 inches in diameter which is tiny compared to other take-out buns.  It was only 60 cents, though, so I really can't complain. 

It was heavily dusted in flour, something strange and new in my world of glazed-over bbq buns.  I took a bite and immediately noticed the sandpapery texture of the outside, not unlike that of a cat's tongue.  Fortunately for me, it was not filled with cat tongue (something that I had grown accustomed to living in Hawaii (all people from Hilo are in on this old manapua joke)) but rather it was filled with a moderately tasty, not-so-syrupy filling.  It had cubes of pork that were all a uniform in size, and were quite delicious, with a great sauce-to-meat ratio.  That aftertaste of red char siu was pleasantly moderate.

This bun would be a solid four-stars if were not for the offensive texture of the bun so I give it a "3", but I'll rate my experience at TCP as a "4".
author: Thomas M.

description:
The food is good and super cheap. Need I say more?  We spent about $10 for 2 people for lunch and grabbed another $10 worth of food to go.  That is HELLA cheap! And mind you, this was after a tiring 20 mile bike ride.  My body just lapped up all that carbs without care.

Tried the crab cake, shrimp shumai, egg tart etc.  There was a bunch of other stuff but I can't think of it all right now.

Since it was quite empty when we got there, the owners let us bring our bikes into the store rather than locking it outside. I thought that was cool. Not many SF establishments lets you bring your bike into the store.

I didn't get to try all the stuff there, especially the desserts.  I think I shall tackle that the next time.
author: Acamar A.

description: My favorite dim sum to go I'm Sunset.  This place has been at the same location for many years.  Dim sum freshly made daily.
author: Chris R.

description: gets five stars cause it has better service than the one in daly city. this is the real t.c. pastry! affordable and delicious
author: Anne Jolene C.

description:
Fish balls on a stick are my favorite, whenever and wherever. Their curry sauce was delicious! Drizzled all over the stick, it was not too spicy but just enough. 

We went to get some coffee, buns, and dessert for the road. The buns - which I ate about 8 hours later while waiting for a connecting flight back to New York - was obviously a bit stale but still tasty. I'm sure it would have been great if I had eaten them fresh.

The black sesame dessert soup we bought was REALLY delicious - not too sickeningly sweet, just the perfect texture. 

My friend the Vegan said his mushroom and veggie buns were great. The buns were really cheap - 3 for $1.90!
author: Melissa L.

description:
This place is a little better than Happy Bakery which is across the street from them. I have been coming here since I was little and it's way better than  Happy Bakery.

The Shrimp Rice noodles are really good and if you go there at night, there is a special going on which is like 3 items for $1.15. I think that's a pretty good deal but you have to heat it up but if you don't mind cold food, well there you go.
author: Maile W.

description:
For a take-out dim sum place, this has got be one of the dirtiest shitholes I've ever seen. Sticky floors and boxes stacked up everywhere, it's pretty putrid. Sometimes there will be flies flying around the establishment. 

However, unnecessary details aside, of all the little carryout dim sum places on Irving, this place is the best. That's saying a lot considering almost every block on lower Irving has a dim sum place. 

Where else can you get a container of porridge for less than $3? Or a bowl of wonton noodle soup to go for $3.50? They also have "Chee Fanh" or "Fanh Tuan" which is glutinous rice, dried shredded pork, and a yao tieu or Chinese donut inside. It's nearly impossible to find a place that has this now! 

Dim sum is pretty satisfactory, and for the prices you pay for, you get a lot of quality. A lot of places mix their shrimp with fatty pork and other unappetizing and unhealthy fillers. This place gives you all shrimp in the shrimp orders. 

There just has to be a certain time to go, such as right before lunch or early in the morning. If you go in the afternoon, majority of the dim sum that you see in the glass counter are cold and the skins have become unchewable, plasticky, and seriously not good eats.
author: Derrick L.

description: We stop here for the Baked BBQ pork buns which we buy a dozen at a time and then keep in the freezer for those times when we want a quick snack (just pop it in the microwave to defrost and then pop into the oven to restore the baked crust).  Other items which are good include the dim sum items, but come early cause they sell out fast.
author: Justin Y.

description: updated review - CONSISTENCY!  been coming here since moving to the city 2 yrs ago.  first went on yelp recs and never disapointed since.  pastry is really good whether curry puff (everyone likes these, just the right meat-sweet-curry mix) pork turnover (makes me think of a savory filo dessert) or spicy fried wonton (addictive flavor crunch).  the pork dumplings are porky goodness and the shrimp cilantro dumplings are well balanced.  fried shrimp cakes perfectly match egg and shrimp, very satisfying.  the prices are super reasonable.  rarely a wait.  take out and have a great meal - breakfast, lunch or dinner.
author: Bob K.

description: Really cheap good dim sum. Really greasy, but thats expected. Just be patient if you don't know chinese, all the people there are chinese speakers.
author: Kristin S.

description: Good simply dim sum in an unpretentious setting. The chicken, beef and shark fin dim sum are excellent, my favorite being the shark fin dim sum. Hey, don't judge until you've tried it! Their steamed pork bums don't impress me though. In fact, I found the filling a little hard to down. But then again I'm not the biggest pork fan in the world anyways.
author: David D.

description:
The food here is actually not bad other than oily and fatty.  

The place is dirty.

The service is as BAD as it can get!

And manner?  Dont think this word exists in their dictionary.

I used to blame the people working there but it all started from above, the owner/management (the short hair older lady), who are mean, rude, nasty.  The words that came out of her mouth is unbelievable.  They treat their employees with no respect.  It is really hard for the employees to smile and serve people right when the owner/mgmt are bitchy 500% of the time.
author: SF F.

description:
I used to live in the neighborhood and this has to be my fave dim sum place. Yes, it's not a nice sit down nor it looks like they care about hygiene, but their dim sum is awesome. I tend to over order everytime I go there. Sorry, can't help myself.

Now I live in Lower Haight, so it's a bit of a travel just to get dim sum as I don't see any other purpose for going to the neighborhood. Though realistically, where exactly can you find dim sum place in Lower Haight?

Anyway, about 5 or 6 months ago I bought their dim sum for me and my husband's lunch. Unfortunately, my husband got a very bad food poisoning. He's positive it's the pork shumai as he said it was rather pink. He got really sick, let me just spare you the gory details, I had to take him to the emergency room that night and he was released at 7am!  It was quite an adventure.

Weirdly, we consumed pretty much the same thing and I was totally fine. It could be just one bad pork shumai among the rest, or his white stomach just can't tolerate a little bit of dirt. Therefore, I'm still going to TC Pastry every once in a while though now I inspect every pork shumai I have. Of course, I have to go there by myself cause my husband is pretty much traumatized.
author: Perry S.

description: There was decidedly no vegetarian options when I stopped by the other day. Although from other yelp reviews, I could have gone with the steamed veggie rolls. Oh well, I got steamed pork buns and pot stickers for folks to share and they loved it. 3 ginormous pot stickers for $1.50 - pretty good deal. Now, if they would have more things for me, I'd be happy :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
If this was anywhere besides the Bay Area, this place would be alright.

I came here for a brunch/lunch on Chinese New Year Eve and brought my goodies back home.

I heated up turnip cakes, chive/shrimp dumplings, and deep fried savory dumplings on a pan so they were crispy and hot.

The food, unfortunately, was still CRAP.

It's oily, funky tasting, CRAP. It might be good if you cover the taste with soy sauce or mustard or something, but I like my dim sum plain so I can taste the typically wonderful flavors.

Needless to say, I'm desperately looking forward to dinner since lunch was such an utter disappointment. The only redeeming part of my trip was getting an all-day MUNI pass.

I better choose my next meal more carefully. 

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description: Went there solely for the sesame balls.  Price is right, 3 for 1.70, and they're very good but a little too greasy for me.
author: Pat P.

description: So thanks to some fellow yelpers I went to this place with my friend. We went there kind of skeptical though because I was thinking it was going to be a dim sum place where you sit and waiters bring trays of food and you pick and enjoy, etc. But no, you order the food from a cafeteria style layout. Then we weren't about to go because we couldn't locate it because of the hole in the wall sort of placement in Irving. But let me tell you, the food is delicious and cheap. I think it cost less than $2 for 3 shrimp dumplings and they were so good I had to order an order to go. The only thing I think that might be caution for people with high expectations is the way the food looks to be sitting out, but trust me it is worth it.
author: Desiree C.

description:
Best snack ever:   Hot & Spicy Fried Won Tons.

Who would have thought a dim sum place would make curry filled wontons that are deep fried?  The curry puffs and egg rolls are also tasty,  but definitely can't compare to king egg roll from the south bay.  The regular dim sum stuff is pretty good, but not great.  So why five stars?  Read the first sentence.  Oh did I mention it's super cheap?
author: Simon Y.

description:
Surprisingly, I only paid $15 and it bought me enough dim sum to fill 4 hungry bellies desiring a quick and greasy snack!

We all really enjoyed the shrimp and cilantro dumplings, steamed rice noodle roll with (not dried) shrimp and steamed rice noodle roll with cilantro and veggies.  Potstickers were beast-sized, but not my fave.

As for the cha siu bau, I'll pass, thanks.  (I know, I'm a bad Asian.)

All in all, it was quick, cheap and tasty (plus the lady tolerated my ABCness and let me order in English/broken Chinese)!
author: Krystle S.

description: Been coming here for quite sometime now.  Always seem to go here early in the morning when I want some dim sum, Chinese donut, and jook for breakfast.  Can't go wrong if you are in the area and need a good & cheap Chinese breakfast...
author: Patrick C.

description:
It would be fantastic if there were a better bulk deal, but at least everything was bloody tasty! Chicken bao, pot stickers, siu mai, ha gow, some other shrimp dumpling situation and a veggie situation.

They were super friendly and accommodating, it was just a bummer to essentially pay retail when I was buying what would have been a wholesale ticket (a few hundred dumplings).

Popular in that neighborhood of the Sunset, which is always a good sign too!
author: D. R.

description: The mushroom buns are the best veggie steamed buns anywhere. All of the steamed dumplings are good as well.. But the place could use a little scrubbing.
author: Mosey S.

description: This is my favorite dim sum joint on Irving! Best baked pork bun in town, the steamed ones are good too.  The sticky rice ball with chinese sausage is another item you HAVE to try there!  A little more expensive than some of their competitors, but worth it!!!
author: Bobby P.

description:
This is for those days when you just can't deal with going to some jam packed tea house and waiting for the cart carrying what you want to FINALLY float by.  

This is for those days you need to grab something quick on Irving while doing your grocery shopping and sugary donuts just aren't going to do it.

This is for the those days you want a simple brunch of congee or some pot stickers.  

This is the one.  The only place to get your take out dim sum on Irving.  The rest just aren't as a good.
author: K W.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 90

HELL YA!

This place is awesome. 

The dim sum is fresh, cheap, and very good.

I got a small chow mien, shrimp and chive dumplings, and a pan fried pork bun for $4. 

So bomb. And it is so fresh and clean, not heavy and greasy. 

I think I'm gonna have to come here every morning before work.
author: Kristina C.

description:
Living in SF has shifted the usual meals with the dad from I-hop to Asian food. Last time the search was for Dim Sum, and somehow it led us here. While dad may be disappointed that the food isn't served on little plates carried to your table, I was delighted by the size (or lack there of) of the place and the prices which for the amount of food you get totally k.o. every dollar menu around (included: the caramel apple empenadas at KFC/Taco Bell).

Yes, it should be noted I'm no Dim Sum expert, but I've been here several times now and the food has always been excellent if a little greasy. Add to it a large selection of chicken filled things, and sweet tasting things, and a solid mushroom dumpling stocked with all kinds of like minded veggies, and you've got (probably) the best meal around for under five dollars. Which of course can easily get you about half the store in any given visit.
author: Stephen M.

description: Disappointed and will definitely not going back.  The shrimp dumplings were semi-cold and the outer layer was hard. Shouldn't they be kept in a steamer?  Also, the woman who handled my food...didn't wash her hands before handling other's money and after scratching the inside of her ear. This brought it from a 3 to a 2 rating.
author: Ria V.

description: The women that work here are bitchy.  Expect to be yelled at.  :(
author: Fatty A.

description:
I love this litlle shack! Very inexpensive and very tasty Dim Sum! I love the taro and rice noodles! Great stuff!

Parking is horrible...as usual.
author: Marc E.

description: I really wish to give this place 3 1/2 stars!  As today was my first time there, I moved to the side to take in the massive menu; which is always a good idea, although there weren't too many people there.  A pork bun lover, I had to have some!  The nice lady said it was fine if I had two baked and one steamed.  I also ordered the shrimp and cilantro dumplings, crab cake (crab enveloped in a mini egg omelette thing and a chinese doughnut.  Everything tasted good; average.  The baked pork buns were smaller than usual, but I didn't mind, as they had a lot of meat.  Yet the outside bread was different from every other baked bun I have had, 1/2 as thick, and not light and airy.  The bread was thin and dense.  Also, there was some sort of gel texture in with whatever sauce they use with the pork, which was also in the steamed bun.  The other items were good, but unfortunately, nothing to draw me back.  Make sure you have a defibrillator if you eat the very generous (about the size of half my arm) chinese doughnut.  I was lucky enough to get it straight from the fryer!  Yowch!  The lady who helped me was super nice!
author: Delicious B.

description: fast, simple, to the point dimsum. you can't do any wrong, you cannot!! prices were unbeatable too :P
author: Karen H.

description: This place is my favorite place to get Pork Buns, Hot Dog Buns and Curry Puffs. I would buy and stock up for 3 days worth of goodness for my lunch break at work. The best are the mini pork buns. You gotta try these little bastards. The bread is baked just right and the sauce in the pork bun is awesome. I use the hot dog buns just like any other hot dogs, cut a slice open, pour in some relish and mustard and that's a meal with a bag of popchips. The curry puffs and the egg custard tarts are awesome. If you want to switch up the style of pork filled goodness try the pork turnover shaped like triangles. I also like the spicy fried wonton and lastly the coconut balls are great. The only thing they don't do well are the cocktail buns. Very plain and mundane go elsewhere for that. All in all 4 days worth of lunch runs me about 10 bucks give or take a buck or two. Not bad for you money savers out there that want to cut down on spending  that much for one day of lunch, give these economically friendly meals a chance.
author: graham c.

description: This place has really great, fresh dim sum to go. I recommend the curry puffs. Even though I don't eat meat, I remember many items from this place as being fantastic, and still get a few veg things there whenever I can.
author: Chris S.

description:
Probably the only place i go to if i wanted dimsum. I always order my usual, beef rice noodle, wheat bun?(not sure what its called in english), and porridge.  I love how they use water chestnut in some of their dishes. 

Generally everything is good in their menu, although i thought the wonton noodle soup was pretty bland but its cheap and fills you up, i recommend to get the fried wontons and curry fishballs and dump them inside your wonton soup. Warning fried wontons make your breath stink. Their mini eggtarts are really good.
author: Eric N.

description: I like the pork buns here.  Its 3 for 1.63  maybe cost more now.  It cheap and near my house.
author: John F.

description: This is a cool little place.  It has no ambiance.  It is pretty much to go dim sum, although they have a few tables. However, the shrimp and cilantro dumplings are great.  They also have good pork buns.  The service is efficient and friendly.  Also, the prices are crazy cheap.
author: Kate B.

description: I just tried the chicken and bitter melon rice noodle roll and it was really good. I'm not a fan of bitter melon, it's alright I just can't eat a whole dish of it, too strong of a taste. But in this rice noodle roll it's perfect! The bitter melon is sliced very thinly and the chicken is seasoned nicely so that it's not overwhelmed by the bitter melon. If you're not afraid of strong flavors then give this dish a try. It's a nice change from shrimp or beef, the usual suspects in rice noodle rolls. In fact, I've never come upon this flavor choice. I think I'll be ordering this over the other two for a while.
author: cyndi L.

description: This is a great place if your on the go, or looking for great cheap eats. If you go in the morning they have the Chinese donuts wrapped in a rice noodle roll which is excellent with the peanut sauce.. etc. I love the har gow, and shu mai here. The jook could do some work on, but i've been coming here for over 10-15 years, i can't complain.
author: Brian P.

description: for the Sunset district, the Dim Sum's pretty good.  They now have four...count it...one, two, three, four...little tables to sit down and gulp down these little delights.  It's great for a quick bite and easy on your wallet.  I particularly like their dried shrimp crepes (har cheung fun) with chili paste.  Mmmmm mmmmm good.  The shrimp dumplings (har gow) are also excellent.  Good chicken buns too!
author: JeFF T.

description: Good taste, high cholesterol. But hey, its delicious....and cheap too.
author: Colleen W.

description: Definitely the best cheapie dim sum spot in SF so far...
author: Rich B.

description: Another plus in the Sunset district. This place is nothing fancy, but good dim sum at inexpensive prices. A good take-out place. Have to come back and try some more stuff here.
author: Leon C.

description: I live in the Sunset and there is no shortage of Dim Sum here. So why TC and not some other shop? Flavor, price, portion size and variety of options. Seriously, they have so much to choose from and it is all good. I love their pork buns and their wheat buns w/ raisins. I stop in here with $2 in my pocket and leave with everything I want.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
The storefront doesn't reflect how good the food is!  Definitely one of the better take out dim sum places in SF. 

Things I've tried:
- mushroom/vegetable steamed bun: 5 stars - delicious.  Just the right balance of veggies.
- curry puff: 5 stars - the dough is fairly sweet, which balances well with the curry filling, that is just a little bit spicy.
- shrimp and chive dumplings: 5 stars - just enough texture and flavor in a thin translucent skin.
- steamed rice noodle with shrimp: 5 stars - big pieces of shrimp in a tender rice noodle -- three big pieces for $2!
- steamed rice noodle with vegetable: 5 stars - it's the same filling as the mushroom/veggie bun - mushrooms, black fungus, carrot
- potsticker: 4 stars - the filling was not heavy at all.  I think there was shrimp and pork in it. 
- steamed rice noodle with bitter melon a
nd chicken: 4 stars - I liked the bitter melon, but wasn't that crazy about the chicken filling.
author: lovetoeat p.

description: Cheap, tasty, close to home, easy to swing by and pick up goodies.  It might move up to 4 stars someday, but for now, only 3.
author: Curtis H.

description: This is my favorite take-out dim sum place on the strip....  Food is fairly well labeled in English for those who are Chinese-language challenged like myself.  The ingredients and skin of the dim sum seems of higher quality compared with those of other take-out joints.  Big variety.  Huge bargain compared with restaurant dim sum (though of course there are compromises).  My favorite, if I can make it there by noon-ish, is the fried donut wrapped with rice noodle.  Egg rolls, sesame balls, and coconut red bean balls are also a hit. The staff are bilingual; I wouldn't say customer service is their strong suit, however, at least they smile at you most of the time.  Four tables available...but don't expect them to be super clean....
author: Kim T.

description: I like the nice selection available at this place, and their presentation of different items on the counter helps when ordering.  The shrimp and cilantro dumplings were wonderful!  There was a little something extra to them, water chestnuts I think, that made them nice and crunchy to bite into.  The steamed buns, as mentioned in other reviews are pretty packed with filling.  The veggie mushroom and the pork buns were both winners.
author: Lauren M.

description: Love this place for having a good variety of poultry dim sum since I don't eat pork or beef. They even have chicken fried dumplings (hom sui gok) which is rare because it's always made of pork. It's very crispy too! I also like their rice noodle rolls. You can have a full lunch here for $3.
author: Al T.

description:
I'm not a huge dim sum fan, and yes, it does seem like there's really nothing different about the dim sum staples here versus any other dim sum place, but this place stands out more to me because they have a lot of different things you don't normally come across. Some things I've tried:

- curry puff: the crust was good. It was on the sweet side, which was interesting. The curry inside was pretty satisfying!
- chicken pot pie: the crust was the same as the curry puff! I didn't really enjoy this as much, probably because of the filling. Meh, I'm not too big of a fan of pot pies either..
- hot n spicy wonton: THIS WAS GOOD! I think it may have been because of the fried wonton wrappers, but the curry inside reminds me of my grandma's. i'm not really sure what was in this (I gobbled it up so quickly) but I think it was just cabbage or something? Not sure.. They're small, but you can get 5 for like 1.25. 
- soy milk: This is pretty good! It's different, because it's homemade. I think it's less than a dollar a cup too. Goes well with the dim sum!
- Curry Fish balls: Mmm. They're not that spicy (which I wanted) but still good.
- Fried Dough wrapped in Rice Noodle Roll: For some reason, the name made it sound better than it was. It does come with soy sauce, and peanut sauce (which I like) but I wasn't that wowed by it
- Coconut Balls: SO GOOD!! I like it when they're slightly cold (but not hard)

They also have some other things I want to try in the future, like the taro puff, and the black sesame soupy thing.  I will definitely return in the future!
author: Bub B.
