description: I used to pop in here to get my quick dim sum fix...that is until I discovered Happy Bakery across the street and a block down.
author: Scott M.

description:
one dirty looking restaurant that most people won't bother walking into. but this place is different.  if you ever had anything here, whether it's quick snack of dim sum or some otther special stuff like egg tart or steam buns you will eventually forgive them on the dirtiness or sticky floor. 

this place is a treasure for hong kongers in the sunset district. many people come here in the morning to pick up early dim sum breakfast to go. they also have a large group of people who visit on regular basis. 

This place is definitely a place to look out for if your ever in a crave for some dim sum orders togo.
author: Eric Y.

description: two words, crispy wonton. anyways I always go here for those things. Theyre crispy and the inside is a yellow curry filling, sooo good! Theyre very cheap too, I think its 5 for $1.20. I've also ordered their beef rice noodle which is quite filling and the chicken suimai. this place is closed on tuesday?, i think.
author: Miss H K.

description:
When we don't want to go to a Tea House and just want quick good dim sum, we head out to TC Pastry.  The place also has porridge and wonton noodles to go for a cheap price.  My favs are the custard buns, noodles with dried shrimp and the haw gows (shrimp dumplings).  

I was taken a back when they put some of the dim sum in plastic bags, but got over it quick because of their cheap prices and that I was going to gobble the food up within the next 20 minutes anyways.
author: c v.

description: Decided to try this place for an unorthodox outing with a friend: pick up dim sum, head to the beach, enjoy a bit of wine. Uncertain whether the "kitchen" at TC Pastry would be closed by the time I arrived, I called in my order. I don't know much about dim sum, and certainly don't know the names of dishes. I asked for recommendations over the phone, and everything sounded good. I figured we could take care of $20 worth of food, no problem. To my surprise, I arrived at the restaurant and found three massive plastic containers filled with food, and more in a bag, all coming out to about $18.50. We got rid of half of it, and it was still $10.83 for so much food. The spicy deep fried pork rolls were my favorite. Everything else was so-so. We only managed to eat 2/3 of it. Overall, the place was pretty good. The quality was sub-par, and most dishes tasted identical. I won't go back, but wish the best to the friendly folks who run it.
author: Kevin A.

description:
From the outside TC Pastry doesn't look like much, actually the inside doesn't look like much either, but when you see a line of people at the counter on weekend mornings, that's gotta tell you something!  TC is pretty much a take-out Dim Sum place with 4 tables if you want to get a quick bite, but what a gem of a place!  The Won Tons in the Won Ton Noodle soup are  meaty with a good sized piece shrimp (if not the whole shrimp) in each dumpling, the noodles are simple but just the right texture and the soup is light and simple.  All this for about 4 bucks!  Other favorites here are the 1000 year old egg & pork jook and the fish & peanut jook.  TC also offers a nice variety of Rice Rolls (Cheung Fun) the usual beef, shrimp or pork, but the Bitter Melon w/ Chicken and the Vegetable Rice Rolls are very nice if you want to try something different.
They also have Spicy (Curry ) Fried Won Tons are a nice twist to the Fried Won Ton enthusiast.  The Black Sesame pudding, paste or soup or whatever they call it offers a nice light and healthy dessert!
author: Doug L.

description: Of all the dim sum places in SF, I always come back to this one. A hole in the wall place with two little tables and no atmosphere, TC is the perfect take out dim sum shop. Having never left me heartbroken, and never leaving me with an empty stomach, TC Pastry has been my favorite sunset dim sum place since I was 13 years old. Is the best? I don't give a shite! All I know is that it has never let me down. Try anything and everything... all hail cheap, great dim sum! Oh, and a few doors down is a good Bubble tea place... yummm!
author: Mitchell W.

description:
well my family & i have been coming here for years, the food is still good & very modestly priced.  

when we get our dim sum craving & not wanting to drive to chinatown for a sit down we come here & take it home.  there are plenty of choices here, they are all pretty fresh & tasty.  we typically will order the dry shrimp rice noodle (cheng fun), 2 orders of fried wonton (jow wonton), 2 orders of the custard tarts (dan tat), turnip cake (lo bak go), sticky rice dumpling (lo mi bow), pork & shrimp dumplings(shew mai), chinese sausage bun (lap chang bow) & what ever else looks good.  typically, we leave with a large bag of dim sum for about 15.00

the decor in the place is is pretty stark & plain.  they do offer eat in or take out.  they do not accept credit cards or checks, its cash only here.  street parking around the area can be a mess.
author: larry s.

description: I used to work in this neighborhood, and I adore dim sum.  Needless to say, I've tried all the places the neighborhood has to offer, and they're by far the best.  My favorites:  Shrimp with cilantro, baked pork buns, crispy wontons, wonton soup, curry puffs, beef rice noodle, aw hell, it's all tasty.
author: Risa S.

description: I used to live in this hood and went there from time to time. It's not the best but there are somethings that are good--like their cheung fun (long, rolled noodle with dried shrimp).  I think their stuff tends to be on the greasy side.
author: Nancy H.

description: Cheap prices.  Variable quality.  I can't give more than 2 stars to a place that puts dumplings in the microwave.  Yikes.  Spicy wontons were definitely the highlight.  Chicken pie, pork buns, pork dumplings all left something to be desired.  Next time I'll spend the money and go to Ton Kiang.
author: Cliff M.

description: All these reviews are lovely, but they neglect the main reason I come here: they're open at 7:30AM.  You can have wonton soup (careful: sometimes not ready until 8:00), fresh mushroom noodle (more expensive than shrimp noodle,  that's how good), and fried curry puffs (fat, fried in fat, some fat with that?).  When even pho places aren't open yet, we come here, the manic early risers, starving hysterical naked etc.  Tea is $0.20.  And I never reviewed this place (how to say "subrosa" in Cantonese?) but now they have a Yelp sticker on their door, so no more cloak and dagger.
author: Non P.

description: yummy! best dimsum take out place i have been to in the sunset area. i love their chun fun, hao gao, and the sticky rice in the lotus leaves. The sui mai is ok, but i've definitely had better at other places. I also tried the custard egg tarts and they weren't as great as I expected them to be... maybe because it was toward the end of the day. Next time I want to try their juk and pork dumplings! Although I wish parking wasn't so hard on irving =(
author: leanna w.

description: the buns are just alright. I'm not a big fan of chinese buns in general though. I like the white sugar things, they're called bak tong gou in chinese.. The porridge with the black eggs is the best thing here though. They give you so much black eggs and the meat is good. It's the best thing to eat when you have a cold. I've been coming to this place my whole life and it's comfort food to me.
author: Ale x.

description: great prices. good pork buns, shrimp cilantro dumplings, and egg custard buns.
author: Kan L.

description: this is the best dim sum place i have been to yet. they have amazing pork buns. they are also cheaper than the rest ive been to. and i am a really big pork bun fan. you can just taste a higher quality in this bun.
author: Alissa S.

description: Well, it's definitely cheap but not worth it if you are really craving a good meal.  I left disappointed.  The best thing was probably the fried daikon cakes because they were fresh. Potstickers were also not bad. Everything else was mediocre:  pork siu mai, bbq pork bun (baked), mushroom roll.  Wonton soup was cheap but also small portion.  Decent but I wouldn't go back for it.
author: Le L.

description: So cheap, and so good.  Best sesame balls ever!  So crispy on the outside, soft on the inside.  Gyoza is EXCELLENT.  Great place to order out for parties, they make great finger foods.
author: zzzulu l.

description: Was walking down Irving looking for a quick bite before an appointment at UCSF. Saw a sign for "Dim Sum Specialists" and couldn't resist. I've heard of dim sum chefs, but specialists? I must investigate. Upon walking in I thought they'd oversold themselves - the place is quite drab and the food presentation designed by a firm believer in pragmatism. But upon viewing and later tasting the food I had been way too quick to judge. 3 shrimp and cilantro balls for under 2 bucks?!? SIGN ME UP. The skin was surprisingly well made and there was a good amount of shrimp. My only complaint is that they were cold.  I also tried their coconut buns (they come in threes, shaped lik hot-dog rolls. Very handsome portion). These were warm and SO SOFT and delicious with the perfect amount of coconut filling. Delicious, filling snack for under 5 bucks. Twas my first and very satisfactory take-out dim sum experience. Specialists indeed. Will stop by next time I'm in the set for some of that deep fried curry puff action.
author: Polly F.

description: we got a variety of dumplings and the shrimp and chive was definately the star. also yummy is the chicken and mushroom dumpling. and great pork buns. didn't love the chicken turnover but everything else was spot on.
author: Tara M.
